TaxonomyNode.Description: Monophonic synthesizer released as an update over the classic Minimoog. Produced from 2002 to 2015.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Moog Voyager

TaxonomyNode.Description: Developed by Hammond and produced from 1940 to 1942. The world's first commercially available polyphonic synthesizer. Unlike most of the rest of Hammond's products, it was not intended to emulate the sound of an organ.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Novachord

TaxonomyNode.Description: Electronic musical instrument developed by the French inventor Maurice Martenot and released in 1928. Playable with the keyboard or by moving a ring along a wire. Prominently used in composer Olivier Messiaen's Turangalîla-Symphonie.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Ondes Martenot

TaxonomyNode.Description: 5-voice polyphonic synthesizer produced by Sequential Circuits from 1978 to 1984. The first musical instrument with its own embedded microprocessor.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Sequential Circuits Prophet 5

TaxonomyNode.Description: Small, stylus-operated synthesizer produced by Brian Jarvis and Dubreq beginning in 1968.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Stylophone

TaxonomyNode.Description: Early electronic instrument developed in 1920 by Soviet inventor Léon Theremin. Played without being touched - two antennas on the instrument detect the position of the player's hands. One hand is used to control frequency and the other is used to control amplitude.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Theremin

TaxonomyNode.Description: 8-voice polyphonic synthesizer produced by Yamaha from 1976 to 1980. Can be prominently heard in Greek composer Vangelis's soundtracks for Blade Runner and Chariots of Fire.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Yamaha CS-80

TaxonomyNode.Description: Small, monophonic, bass synthesizer released by Novation in 1993, the Novation Bass Station provided affordable mimicry of the Roland TB-303.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Novation Bass Station

TaxonomyNode.Description: Stomp box that turns normal guitar sounds into synthesizer-like sounds.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Guitar Synth

TaxonomyNode.Description: Small, cheap and cheap-sounding line of electronic keyboards produced for home use, especially for children. Formerly common in garage rock bands and amateur music productions. Used in professionally recorded music for its distinctively cheap, tinny sound.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Casiotone

TaxonomyNode.Description: Line of analog modeling (or virtual analog - a term for DSP that mimics analog processes) subtractive synthesizers produced by Clavia beginning in 1994.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Clavia Nord Lead

TaxonomyNode.Description: Electronic instrument that emulates the sound and playing style of the bagpipes.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Electronic Bagpipes (Electronic Wind Instrument)

TaxonomyNode.Description: Wind controller electronic musical instrument that emulates the playing style of woodwind instruments such as the clarinet and saxophone.
TaxonomyNode.Name: EWI (Electronic Wind Instrument)

TaxonomyNode.Description: Highly popular, portable, and affordable virtual analog synthesizer and vocoder produced by Korg beginning in 2002.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Korg Microkorg

TaxonomyNode.Description: Semimodular, single-oscillator, monophonic synthesizer produced by Korg from 1978 to 1981. Particularly popular among late 1980s and 1990s electronic musicians, such as techno pioneer Juan Atkins and ambient house innovators The Orb. Especially renowned for its large-feeling bass sounds.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Korg MS-10

TaxonomyNode.Description: 8-voice polyphonic synthesizer released by Korg in 1980. Features independent sections for string emulation, brass emulation, and more distinctly electronic synthesizer sounds.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Korg Trident

TaxonomyNode.Description: Invented by Bill Bernardi and manufactured by Computone, Inc., the Lyricon was the first EWI to ever be constructed.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Lyricon (Electronic Wind Instrument)

TaxonomyNode.Description: Popular line of polyphonic synthesizers released by Roland in the 1980s - the Juno-6, the Juno-60, and the Juno-106.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Roland Juno

TaxonomyNode.Description: Popular 6-voice, polyphonic, analog synthesizer with digitally controlled oscillators, released in 1982 as a successor to the Roland Juno-6 and produced through 1984, when it was replaced by another update, the Juno-106.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Roland Juno-60

TaxonomyNode.Description: 8-voice polyphonic subtractive synthesizer produced by Roland Corporation from 1981 to 1985. Can be heard on many prominent recordings, such as Marvin Gaye's "Sexual Healing" and Duran Duran's "Hungry Like The Wolf".
TaxonomyNode.Name: Roland Jupiter-8

TaxonomyNode.Description: Popular polyphonic string synth released by Roland in 1978.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Roland Paraphonic Strings RS-505

TaxonomyNode.Description: Monophonic bass synthesizer sold by Roland from 1981 to 1984. Initially marketed as a replacement for bass guitars, but commercially flopped in that capacity. Later picked up by electronic musicians, its signature "squelchy" sounds became a hallmark of the popular acid genre, making the instrument massively popular in the late 1980s.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Roland TB-303

TaxonomyNode.Description: Early digital synthesizer, produced from the late 1970s through the early 1990s. Featured in many prominent recordings - for example, it produced the gong sound at the beginning of Michael Jackson's "Beat It".
TaxonomyNode.Name: Synclavier

TaxonomyNode.Description: The first commercially successful digital synthesizer, the DX7 generates sound using Frequency Modulation Synthesis. Its glassy, harsh, and cold sounds came to dominate 80s pop, opposed to earlier analog synthesizers, which sounded warmer and fuzzier. Significant artists who used the DX7 include Prince, Phil Collins, A-Ha, Luther Vandross, and Billy Ocean. Producer Brian Eno also popularized the ambient capabilities of the synthesizer by using it heavily in his work.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Yamaha DX7

TaxonomyNode.Description: Any instrument primarily distinguished by its use of the Western musical keyboard.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Keyboard

TaxonomyNode.Description: Keyboard instrument which produces sound by plucking or striking strings.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Acoustic Keyboard

TaxonomyNode.Description: European stringed keyboard instrument used from medieval times through the Classical period. The strings are struck with small metal blades called tangents. The instrument is rather quiet, and because of this, was historically used as a practice instrument and compositional aid.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Clavichord

TaxonomyNode.Description: Keyboard instrument used in Europe from the 1500s to the 1800s. The keys control plectrums which pluck the strings. It is particularly associated with Baroque music. Compared to later keyboard instruments such as the fortepiano, which strike rather than pluck strings, it lacks dynamic range.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Harpsichord

TaxonomyNode.Description: Smaller harpsichord with strings set at an angle of about 30 degrees to the keyboard, going to the right. Like all harpsichords, the keys control plectrums which pluck the strings to produce sound.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Spinet

TaxonomyNode.Description: Smaller, simpler harpsichord, with strings set parallel to the keyboard. Like all harpsichords, the keys control plectrums which pluck the strings to produce sound.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Virginals

TaxonomyNode.Description: Soft and twinkly-sounding small 3-5 octave keyboard in which hammers strike steel bars placed over wooden resonators.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Celesta

TaxonomyNode.Description: Keyboard instrument designed in the 1860s. It produces sound with felt hammers which strike pitched tuning forks.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Dulcitone

TaxonomyNode.Description: Keyboard instrument in which struck strings, reeds, or tines are electronically amplified.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Electric Piano

TaxonomyNode.Description: Electric piano from the 1970s produced by Crumar.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Crumar Roadrunner 2

TaxonomyNode.Description: Electric piano produced by Hohner from the 60s through the 80s. There are two primary designs, those prior to 1977, and those from 1977 to the end of production. The earlier models feature stainless steel reeds for producing sound, variable capacitance pick-ups, and leather activation pads. The later models feature rolled spring-steel reeds, electro-magnetic pick-ups, and molded silicone rubber activation pads. It can be heard on recordings such as "Let It Be" by The Beatles and "Joy to the World" by Three Dog Night.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Pianet

TaxonomyNode.Description: Keyboard instrument with hammer-struck metal tines which are amplified via an electromagnetic pickup plugged into an external amplifier and speaker. The first proper Fender Rhodes was released in the mid-1960s, as an improvement on an earlier design that Harold Rhodes created to provide an affordable keyboard for the military to use in therapy for recovering soldiers. The Fender Rhodes has a warm, distinctive sound that has played a major role in jazz since the late 1960s, and which has been prominently used by other popular artists and bands such as Stevie Wonder, Donny Hathaway, and Steely Dan.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Rhodes

TaxonomyNode.Description: A range of different electric piano models produced by Wurlitzer from the mid-1950s through the early 80s. Wurlitzer Electric Pianos are keyboard instruments with hammer-struck metal reeds which are amplified via an electromagnetic pickup plugged into an external amplifier and speaker.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Wurlitzer Electric Piano

TaxonomyNode.Description: Electro-acoustic grand piano produced from 1976 to 1985. It was intended by Yamaha to be a touring friendly and electronically amplified variant of a grand piano. It has real piano keyboard action, with hammers striking strings. A piezo type pick-up system translates the vibrating strings into electric signals. A purple Yamaha CP-80 was famously used by Prince.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Yamaha CP-80

TaxonomyNode.Description: Electrically amplified clavichord invented by Ernst Zacharias and manufactured by Hohner from the 1960s to the early 1980s. Pressing the keys causes small rubber pads to perform a "hammer on" on the steel strings, the vibrations of which are transmitted by electro-magnetic pick-ups to an amplifier. The Clavinet can be heard in many major funk and R&B recordings, such as Stevie Wonder's "Superstition" and War's "Low Rider".
TaxonomyNode.Name: Clavinet

TaxonomyNode.Description: Any keyboard instrument which produces sound by playing back recorded samples when keys are pressed.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Sample-Based Keyboard

TaxonomyNode.Description: Developed by Wisconsin inventor Harry Chamberlin and produced from 1956 up to the early 80s. An innovative keyboard instrument with key-triggered tape heads that activate and play back seconds-long clips of instrument recordings. Harry Chamberlin recorded most of the sounds himself in his home studio. Only officially distributed in the US and Canada. The famous Mellotron was developed as a somewhat illicit copy of Chamberlin instruments brought to the UK by a Chamberlin salesman. The Chamberlin can be heard on David Bowie's Low, as well as on many other major recordings from the 60s and 70s.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Chamberlin

TaxonomyNode.Description: Keyboard instrument that reads tape loops of recorded instruments to generate sound. It also has preset loops of full bands. The Mellotron was developed in 1963 as a somewhat illicit copy of tape-based Chamberlin instruments stolen and brought to the UK by a Chamberlin salesman. Prominently featured on "Strawberry Fields Forever" by The Beatles and "Space Oddity" by David Bowie, in addition to many other rock recordings of the 60s and 70s.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Mellotron

TaxonomyNode.Description: Developed as a professional version of the Optigan (a consumer-focused organ which reads optical discs containing instrument and band recordings to produce sound). The Orchestron's violin sounds can be prominently heard on Foreigner's "Cold as Ice". Compared to the more popular and common Chamberlin and Mellotron, the Orchestron is known primarily for its low fidelity and murky atmospheres.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Vako Orchestron

TaxonomyNode.Description: Consumer-focused keyboard instrument produced in the 1970s by Optigan Corporation, a subsidiary of Mattel. Plastic discs could be loaded in, from which preset accompaniments and sounds could be played. Despite its intention for the consumer market, sounds recorded for and on the Optigan have found their way into many professional recordings, including recordings by Fiona Apple and Blur, and the soundtrack to the third season of David Lynch's Twin Peaks.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Optigan

TaxonomyNode.Description: Keyboard instrument with chromatic keys which, when pressed, move hammers to hit strings in the body of the instrument. There are also foot pedals for dampening and sustaining the sound.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Piano

TaxonomyNode.Description: Earlier, slightly different version of the modern piano - the instrument for which Mozart, Haydn, Beethoven in his youth and their contemporaries wrote their piano music. Softer and with less sustain than modern pianos, Fortepianos also tend to have quite different tone quality in their different registers – slightly buzzing in the bass, "tinkling" in the high treble, and more rounded (closest to the modern piano) in the mid range. Common between 1700 and the early 1800s.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Fortepiano

TaxonomyNode.Description: Large piano in which the strings are horizontal and the action lies below the strings. Has a brilliant, singing and sustaining tone quality.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Grand Piano

TaxonomyNode.Description: Hybrid piano with an extended range that produces cimbalon-like sounds. It also has register stops which change the sound of certain registers of the instrument. Used in a few pieces by Maurice Ravel.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Lutheal

TaxonomyNode.Description: Upright piano with exposed strings on a grand piano shaped plate.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Piano Harp

TaxonomyNode.Description: Self-playing piano containing a pneumatic or electro-mechanical mechanism that operates the piano action via pre-programmed music recorded on perforated paper, or in rare instances, metallic rolls, with more modern implementations using MIDI.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Pianola

TaxonomyNode.Description: Piano with various alterations, such as objects like screws and wires placed in between the piano strings. Popularized by John Cage.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Prepared Piano

TaxonomyNode.Description: Piano with a square shape in which the strings lay horizontally and diagonally in the body of the piano. The most popular keyboard instrument of the late 18th century, it enjoyed continued popularity through the 19th century, but was eventually eclipsed in popularity by the upright piano.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Square Piano

TaxonomyNode.Description: Piano with tacks or nails placed in the hammers so the metal part strikes the strings.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tack Piano

TaxonomyNode.Description: Piano with vertical strings. Not as brilliant-sounding as a typical grand piano, but generally more affordable and more portable.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Upright Piano

TaxonomyNode.Description: Instruments that are struck either with sticks, mallets, or hands to produce sound.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Percussion

TaxonomyNode.Description: Any set of multiple percussion instruments played together.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Percussion Section

TaxonomyNode.Description: Includes many instruments, such as shakers, rope-tensioned skin-headed drums, and mallet instruments. Well known African percussion instruments include Djembe, Shekere, Talking Drum, Udu, Caxixi, etc.
TaxonomyNode.Name: African Percussion

TaxonomyNode.Description: Instruments include various sizes of drums, bells and shakers. Popular instruments include Pandeiro, Surdo, Repinique, Tamborim, Agogo bells, etc.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Brazilian Percussion

TaxonomyNode.Description: Differs based on culture. Some examples include taiko drums in Japanese culture and frame drums in Celtic and Scandinavian cultures.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Folkloric Percussion

TaxonomyNode.Description: Percussion instruments primarily used in Latin music, such as timbales, cowbells, bongos, congas, cabasas, claves, güiros, maracas, etc. Many of these instruments are based on African predecessor instruments.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Latin Percussion

TaxonomyNode.Description: Percussion instruments used in an orchestra. Typical instruments include timpani, bass drum, snare drum, cymbals, auxiliary percussion instruments, and various mallet instruments, such as the marimba and glockenspiel.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Orchestral Percussion

TaxonomyNode.Description: Traditional Māori percussion instruments from New Zealand. Many of the instruments are meant to imitate nature's sounds. Pahū Pounamu is the main percussion instrument used in Taonga Puoro. It is a gong instrument made of wood, greenstone, and whale jawbone.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Taonga Puoro

TaxonomyNode.Description: Percussion instruments which produce pitches and can be played melodically.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Pitched

TaxonomyNode.Description: Two or more forged metal bells. Agogo in Yoruba means single or multiple bells. Agogo bells are believed to be the oldest samba instrument.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Agogo Bells

TaxonomyNode.Description: Drums with a single head attached to a metal bowl. The tension and pitch of the drums are changed by a foot pedal.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Timpani

TaxonomyNode.Description: A wooden xylophone instrument used in Indonesia and the southern Philippines. Typically played in gamelan music and kulintang music.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Gambang

TaxonomyNode.Description: An Indonesian instrument made of carved pitched bamboo tubes.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Angklung

TaxonomyNode.Description: A West African drum with an hour glass shape. The two heads of the drum are connected by ropes. Head tension is changed when the ropes are squeezed under the performer's arm. The performer's other arm is used to play the drum with a curved stick. The pitch of the drum is controlled in patterns to mimic talking.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Talking Drum

TaxonomyNode.Description: A small, high-pitched, metallic mallet instrument, often used in orchestras.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Glockenspiel

TaxonomyNode.Description: The main hand drum used for rhythm-keeping in Nepalese Music.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Madal

TaxonomyNode.Description: Tibetan Singing Bowls are pitched bowls that are struck or rubbed around the edge with a stick or mallet to produce a sustained note.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Singing Bowls

TaxonomyNode.Description: A jug which produces a tone when blown into.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Jug

TaxonomyNode.Description: Sometimes referred to as tubular bells, Chimes are pitched metal tubes struck with hammers. They also usually have dampening mechanisms.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Chimes

TaxonomyNode.Description: A Hindu bell instrument placed in a Temple.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Temple Bell

TaxonomyNode.Description: A pair of Indian drums with skin heads on ceramic bowls. One drum is high-pitched, with a ringing sound quality, and the other is low-pitched. The pitch of each drum varies with the amount of pressure placed on the head.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tabla

TaxonomyNode.Description: Steel Drums originate from Trinidad and Tobago. A concave piece of steel with many dimples that produce different pitches when struck.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Steel Drums

TaxonomyNode.Description: A rotating cylinder with attached, pitched, glass bowls. A performer touches the bowls and the bowls vibrate in response. Invented by Benjamin Franklin in 1761.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Glass Harmonica

TaxonomyNode.Description: Tuned rocks that are struck like a xylophone to produce sounds.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Lithophone

TaxonomyNode.Description: Musical Saw is held between the legs and bowed with a violin bow. The saw is bent and manipulated to change the pitch produced.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Saw

TaxonomyNode.Description: Small, cymbal-like bells. Common Tibetan bells used are Tingsha and Shang.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tibetan Bells

TaxonomyNode.Description: Hand-held, tuning fork-type chimes rung in a similar way to hand bells. Originally intended to be a training tool for prospective handbell ringers, they are now often rung in conjunction with handbells.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Hand Chimes

TaxonomyNode.Description: A mallet instrument with aluminum bars and a foot controlled sustain system. Each bar of a Vibraphone is paired with a resonator tube with a motor-driven butterfly valve at the upper end. All the valves are mounted on a common shaft, which, powered by an electronic motor, can spin and produce a tremolo or vibrato effect. Common in jazz music, particularly in "Tiki lounge" exotica.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Vibraphone

TaxonomyNode.Description: Small, chromatically tuned brass discs which produce sound when struck with a mallet. The sound is shimmery and rich in overtones.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Crotales

TaxonomyNode.Description: A single string attached to a stick. The string is struck with another stick and resonates through a resonator on the back of the tension stick.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Berimbau

TaxonomyNode.Description: A two-headed drum used in multiple cultures throughout southeast Asia.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Kendang

TaxonomyNode.Description: An Afro-Cuban percussion instrument - a pair of small open bottom drums (one high, one low).
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bongos

TaxonomyNode.Description: A circle of pitched, tuned, bossed gongs that are used in Thai Classical Music. Larger and lower-pitched than the khong whong lek.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Khong Wong Yai

TaxonomyNode.Description: African musical instrument consisting of small, pitched, metal tines attached to a wooden board (often fitted with a resonator).
TaxonomyNode.Name: Mbira

TaxonomyNode.Description: A marimba-like mallet instrument from Thailand with bars suspended by strings and sticks.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Pong Lang

TaxonomyNode.Description: An African xylophone instrument that has been around since at least the 12th century.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Balafon

TaxonomyNode.Description: A set of five pitched blocks made out of wood or composited plastics that are struck with mallets or sticks.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Temple Blocks

TaxonomyNode.Description: Tall, narrow, single-headed drums from Cuba. Used in Afro-Cuban Music.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Congas

TaxonomyNode.Description: A medium-to-high-pitched mallet instrument with wooden bars struck with a hard rubber or plastic mallet.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Xylophone

TaxonomyNode.Description: A large mallet instrument with bars made of rosewood or other woods. Derived from ancient African xylophone instruments.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Marimba

TaxonomyNode.Description: A traditional Indonesian kind of music. There are many Gamelan instruments including Bonang, Gendèr, Gongs, Kendang, Kenong, Peking, Saron, and Slenthem.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Gamelan

TaxonomyNode.Description: Metal or wood instruments with pitched tongues carved into the face of the instrument. When the tongues are struck, they produce a pitched sound.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tongue Drum

TaxonomyNode.Description: Long, single-head tube drums. Basically small but deep tom-toms.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Octoban

TaxonomyNode.Description: Hand-held bells rung by one or multiple performers.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Hand Bells

TaxonomyNode.Description: A drum made and used for Jamaican Nyabinghi music.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Binghi Drum

TaxonomyNode.Description: A Thai xylophone like mallet instrument.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Ranat

TaxonomyNode.Description: A tuned percussion instrument with shallow, steel bars, made by the J.C. Deagan Company in the early 20th century. It has a similar timbre to the celesta.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Marimbaphone

TaxonomyNode.Description: A kalimba-like, Afro-Caribbean instrument with pluckable metal tines. The performer sits on the instrument, similar to with a cajon. It is generally used to play basslines.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Marímbula

TaxonomyNode.Description: Small, kettle-shaped Indian drums used in the folk music traditions of Uttar Pradesh and Punjab, as well as in Bangladeshi Bual music.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Duggi

TaxonomyNode.Description: Metal tines attached to a pan that is partially filled with water. The tines are struck or bowed to produce sound, and the pitch and resonance of the instrument is controlled by manipulating the water in the pan.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Waterphone

TaxonomyNode.Description: A tennis racket with a drum head instead of strings.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Paddle Drums

TaxonomyNode.Description: Drum heads on frames that rotate. Rotating the drum heads increases and decreases tension, making them easily tunable.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Rototoms

TaxonomyNode.Description: A table of pitched wine glasses played by fingers rubbed on the rim. An ancestor of the glass harmonica.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Glass Harp

TaxonomyNode.Description: Shallow, single-headed drums with metal shells used in Latin music. The player, or timbalero, can play very expressively using a variety of stick strokes, rim shots, and rolls. It is often as a featured or solo instrument, as typified by the virtuosic timbalero Tito Puente.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Timbales

TaxonomyNode.Description: A massive instrument consisting of a set of at least 23 bronze, cup-shaped bells hung in the bell tower of a church or municipal entity. Commonly found on American college campuses. The bells are played by keyboards resembling the form of a typical keyboard, but in which the keys are large lever-like sticks called batons. The batons can be pressed down by hands (and feet, as carillons often have pedal keyboards in addition to hand keyboards) to mechanically activate levers and wires connected to metal clappers that strike the inside of the bells.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Carillon

TaxonomyNode.Description: A circle of 18 high-pitched, tuned bossed gongs used in classical Thai Music. Smaller and higher in pitch than the khong whong yai.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Khong Wong Lek

TaxonomyNode.Description: A small, metal instrument, which is placed in the mouth. A piece of metal is plucked with the finger and the pitch and harmonic content of the sound is shaped with the mouth.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Jawharp

TaxonomyNode.Description: A xylophone with an extended lower range - it extends into the lower range of the marimba, thus the name Xylorimba.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Xylorimba

TaxonomyNode.Description: Percussion Instruments that are not made to have certain pitch. Played percussively rather than melodically.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Unpitched

TaxonomyNode.Description: An anvil struck with a hammer or metal mallet. Brake drums or various metal objects are often used in place of an actual anvil.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Anvil

TaxonomyNode.Description: Drum sticks. They can hit stuff or be clicked together.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Drum Sticks

TaxonomyNode.Description: An Indian, two-headed, hourglass-shaped drum. The heads are perforated with seven or eight holes.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Urumee

TaxonomyNode.Description: Teeny tiny cymbals that are sometimes attached to the fingers. They are attached to one another by a string and are struck together.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Finger Cymbals

TaxonomyNode.Description: A scraper instrument of African origin.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Reco-Reco

TaxonomyNode.Description: A wooden frog with ridges on its back. A stick is dragged across the ridges to produce a croaking noise.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Frog

TaxonomyNode.Description: An Argentinian drum with a shell made from a hollowed tree trunk and a head made from animal skin.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bombo Leguero

TaxonomyNode.Description: A large metal shaker instrument from the Caribbean Coast of Colombia.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Guache

TaxonomyNode.Description: Pots and Pans hit with sticks or mallets.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Pots And Pans

TaxonomyNode.Description: Two cymbals pressed together facing opposite ways with their edges touching. They can open and close, and are controlled by a foot pedal.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Hi-Hat

TaxonomyNode.Description: A Persian goblet drum. The principal percussion instrument of Persian music.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tompak

TaxonomyNode.Description: A rattle played by shaking it with one hand and hitting it with the other in the Malagasy music of Madagascar.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Katsa

TaxonomyNode.Description: A washboard performed by scraping the ribbed metal surface. Prominent in the American Southern genres of zydeco, skiffle, jug band music, and old-time music, as well as in early jazz.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Washboard

TaxonomyNode.Description: A small, double-headed, hourglass-shaped drum used in Hindu and Tibetan Buddhist rituals.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Damaru

TaxonomyNode.Description: A block of wood with a resonant chamber carved out of the side. The instrument is struck on the top surface with a stick or mallet and it makes a loud clicking or popping sound.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Wood Block

TaxonomyNode.Description: A pair of hardwood sticks used to make a hollow sounds when struck together.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Claves

TaxonomyNode.Description: A Brazilian, snare-like instrument.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Caixa

TaxonomyNode.Description: A hollow sphere on a stick with beads inside.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Rattle

TaxonomyNode.Description: A single-head, wooden frame drum from Northern Africa and Southwest Asia.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bendir

TaxonomyNode.Description: Just sticks.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Sticks

TaxonomyNode.Description: An Indian two-headed, lug-tensioned drum used in folk and wedding music.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Naal

TaxonomyNode.Description: A gourd with a woven net of beads around it. The instrument is shaken to rattle the beads against the dried gourd.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Shekere

TaxonomyNode.Description: A lathed and hammered disc of metal that is struck with a stick on the edge of the cymbal.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Cymbal (Crash)

TaxonomyNode.Description: A sacred, ancient Egyptian instrument consisting of a metal frame with transverse metal rods that rattle when the instrument is shaken. Similar in sound, though definitely not in appearance, to the tambourine. Still used today as a liturgical instrument in the Ethiopian Orthodox Church.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Sistrum

TaxonomyNode.Description: Small shell like pieces of would strung together in pairs clicked and clacked together with the hands.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Castanet

TaxonomyNode.Description: A small frame drum with many pairs of jingles. Hey, Mr. Tambourine Man, play a song for me…
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tambourine

TaxonomyNode.Description: A portable, traditional English snare drum.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tabor

TaxonomyNode.Description: An Indian barrel-shaped drum used in temple, folk, and Carnatic music.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Thavil

TaxonomyNode.Description: Two pieces of wood hinged together so they can be pushed together to make a slapping sound.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Slapstick

TaxonomyNode.Description: A large, low-pitched, skin-headed drum, mounted on a frame and struck with a large (usually wool or felt) mallet.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bass Drum (Concert)

TaxonomyNode.Description: A Nigerian slit drum.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Oborom Drum

TaxonomyNode.Description: Woodblocks wrapped in sand paper and rubbed together.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Sand Blocks

TaxonomyNode.Description: An Asian bell with a half dome of solid metal and a bottom portion of metal tines. There is a dangling metal piece inside the bell which strikes the sides of the bell.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Elephant Bell

TaxonomyNode.Description: A large yet shallow two headed drum originating in the middle east.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Dohol

TaxonomyNode.Description: A slit drum / log drum. A log with a slit carved in it and played with sticks. Originating in the Congo region.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Lokole

TaxonomyNode.Description: A circular tuned metal plate originating in Southeast Asia.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Gong

TaxonomyNode.Description: Two spoons held in one hand and clicked together in various ways.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Spoons

TaxonomyNode.Description: A horse, donkey, or cattle jawbone that has jingles or rattles that make noise when the instrument is struck. Can sometimes be interchanged with a vibraslap.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Jawbone

TaxonomyNode.Description: A hollowed instrument with grains or beads inside. When it is shaken, the grains or beads rattle around inside and create noise.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Shaker

TaxonomyNode.Description: A large Middle Eastern frame drum.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Daf

TaxonomyNode.Description: A single-headed, long-bodied drum, played with one hand and one stick. It is a traditional drum of the Serer people of Senegal and Gambia.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Sabar

TaxonomyNode.Description: Percussive sounds created by striking or slapping the body.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Body Percussion

TaxonomyNode.Description: A Brazilian snare drum. Shallower than the caixa.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tarol

TaxonomyNode.Description: A wooden box instrument originating from Peru with a thin side which is hit and slapped by the performer.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Cajon

TaxonomyNode.Description: Santa's Reindeer sounding things.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Sleigh Bells

TaxonomyNode.Description: A metal bell struck with a stick. Used commonly in Latin music. Favored by Christopher Walken.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Cowbell

TaxonomyNode.Description: A hollow wooden stick with beads inside that trickle down and sound like rain when the stick is turned upside down.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Rainstick

TaxonomyNode.Description: A two-headed drum. Perhaps the most prominent is a type used in Dominican merengue music, traditionally made from old rum barrels. There are many other national variants of the Tambora, from Argentina, Bolivia, and Colombia to Mexico and Venezuela.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tambora

TaxonomyNode.Description: A North Indian double-headed terracotta pot drum played with the palms and fingers.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Khol

TaxonomyNode.Description: A thin sheet of metal attached to a handle. There are two beaters that are attached to the sheet of metal that strike the metal when the instrument is shaken. The performer bends the metal sheet to change the pitch.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Flexatone

TaxonomyNode.Description: A hollow gourd with ridges on one side that are scraped with a small stick.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Güiro

TaxonomyNode.Description: An Indian shaker instrument with tambourine jingles.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Khartal

TaxonomyNode.Description: A two-headed, hour glass-shaped drum, with one head larger than the other. Used by natives of Yoruba.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Batá

TaxonomyNode.Description: Bottles pitched by filling with different amounts of water. Sound is produced by striking the bottle or blowing across the opening of the bottle.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bottles

TaxonomyNode.Description: A Portuguese shaker with metal jingles.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Chocalho

TaxonomyNode.Description: A lathed and hammered disc of metal that is rolled on with mallets to make a whoosh effect.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Cymbal (Suspended)

TaxonomyNode.Description: A Brazilian hand drum derived from the caxambu drum.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Timbau

TaxonomyNode.Description: A metal triangle struck with a metal beater. Makes a ding-a-ling sound.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Triangle

TaxonomyNode.Description: Metal cans… pretty much how it sounds. You hit them with sticks and stuff.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Metal Cans

TaxonomyNode.Description: Indian finger cymbals.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Taal

TaxonomyNode.Description: A spherical clay pot with an open stem and a big hole on the side. Udu is a Igbo word meaning 'vessel'. The Udu is played by quickly hitting the big hole, which produces a bass sound. The pitch can be changed by adjusting the position of the hand above the upper hole at the top of the stem. Traditionally played by Igbo women for ceremonial use.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Udu

TaxonomyNode.Description: A cylinder of wood that is turned by a crank. The wood is wrapped with a belt that creates friction and a wind-like noise when the crank is turned.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Wind Machine

TaxonomyNode.Description: An ancient Indian instrument with two rope-tensioned heads.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Mridangam

TaxonomyNode.Description: A general term for a guiro-like instrument (any in which sound is produced by scraping its ridges), as well as a specific term for a scratcher used in the musical traditions of Trinidad & Tobago. In the Trini one, a cylinder made from a sheet of aluminum punched with nail holes is scraped with a teethed comb (often an afro pick).
TaxonomyNode.Name: Scratcher

TaxonomyNode.Description: A two-headed Indian folk drum with a large head and a small head.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Dholak

TaxonomyNode.Description: A large Greek tambourine popularly used in music of the Epirus region.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Defi

TaxonomyNode.Description: An Afghani folk instrument - a goblet-shaped, single-headed drum.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Zerbaghali

TaxonomyNode.Description: Drum sticks used together. One of the sticks has ridges.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Rhythm Stick

TaxonomyNode.Description: An ancient, single-head frame drum, struck with one hand. Commonly played in the Middle East and North Africa.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tar

TaxonomyNode.Description: A large bass drum used in Brazilian Baterias.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Surdo

TaxonomyNode.Description: A broad range of Japanese percussion instruments. In Japanese, Taiko means drum, but outside of Japan, Taiko generally refers to the Wadaiko forming a Taiko ensemble.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Taiko

TaxonomyNode.Description: Meaning box in Spanish, Caja is a small drum held between the legs and played with the hands.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Caja

TaxonomyNode.Description: A small, tambourine-like frame drum used in Arabic music. The smaller cousin of the Mazhar. Unlike many other frame drums, it is often played alone, rather than simultaneously as the player sings. It is typically played dramatically and freely, alternating between being violently shaken above the head and lowered down to the knee.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Riq

TaxonomyNode.Description: A Clay Pot struck with a mallet.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Claypot

TaxonomyNode.Description: A Tibetan two-headed drum with a wooden shell.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Rnga

TaxonomyNode.Description: Slapping the cheeks and mouth while manipulating the tongue and cheeks to change the resonant pitch of the mouth. See Bobby McFerrin.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Mouth Percussion

TaxonomyNode.Description: Give me some knucks, bro.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Knuckles

TaxonomyNode.Description: A large, low-pitched drum that is usually a part of a drum set. It rests on its side on the floor and is struck by a beater attached to a foot pedal.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bass Drum (Kick)

TaxonomyNode.Description: A small drum with a long, thin spring attached to one head. The spring sounds like thunder when shaken.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Spring Drum

TaxonomyNode.Description: Two bones that click clack together. Used throughout many cultures.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bones

TaxonomyNode.Description: Various sized shakers with wood shells attached to the bottom of small woven baskets.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Caxixi

TaxonomyNode.Description: Small metal tubes or bars hung from a piece of wood that produce sound when two of the bars or tubes touch.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Wind Chimes

TaxonomyNode.Description: A single-headed drum with a string attached to the head which is plucked. Originating in India.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Khamak

TaxonomyNode.Description: Hawaiian feathered gourd rattles, similar to maracas.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Uli Uli

TaxonomyNode.Description: Various plastic woodblock like instruments.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Jam Block

TaxonomyNode.Description: A large sheet of metal that is shaken to sound like thunder.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Thunder Sheet

TaxonomyNode.Description: A tin tube with holes punched through it. The tub is scraped with a stiff metal brush. The guira is a Dominican instrument.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Güira

TaxonomyNode.Description: Various African rope-tensioned, single-headed drums with an upside down teardrop shape.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Nagara

TaxonomyNode.Description: Also known as tbel, a Ganga is a large double-headed drum, played with one curved stick and one straight stick. It originated from Morocco.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Ganga

TaxonomyNode.Description: An Irish Frame Drum.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bodhrán

TaxonomyNode.Description: Snap yo fingers! Do ya step! You can do it all by yoself!
TaxonomyNode.Name: Finger Snaps

TaxonomyNode.Description: Moroccan hand cymbals that are tied to the fingers and clanged together.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Qarkabeb

TaxonomyNode.Description: The name for a family of West African drums. The drums have rawhide skin heads on both sides and are rope-tensioned.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Dunun

TaxonomyNode.Description: Variously sized planks of wood or stone struck with the butt end of large sticks.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Txalaparta

TaxonomyNode.Description: A rope-tuned, single-head, hourglass-shaped drum originating in West Africa. It is a loud, versatile, solo drum.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Djembe

TaxonomyNode.Description: An Indian Jaw Harp.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Muharsing

TaxonomyNode.Description: A large, two-headed, Turkish drum, played with mallets and sticks.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Davul

TaxonomyNode.Description: A shallow drum with wires stretched across one of the drum heads giving it a "crack" sound when played.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Snare Drum

TaxonomyNode.Description: Dhol can refer to many different two headed drums in India and Pakistan.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Dhol

TaxonomyNode.Description: A large, heavy tambourine instrument, used in Arabic music. The larger cousin of the riq.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Mazhar

TaxonomyNode.Description: The vibraslap is a percussion instrument consisting of a piece of stiff wire (bent into a U-shape) connecting a wood ball to a hollow box of wood with metal “teeth” inside. The percussionist holds the metal wire in one hand and strikes the ball (usually against the palm of their other hand). The box acts as a resonating body for a metal mechanism placed inside with a number of loosely fastened pins or rivets that vibrate and rattle against the box. The instrument is a modern version of the jawbone.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Vibraslap

TaxonomyNode.Description: A cylindrical drum with no snares and less tensioned heads.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Toms

TaxonomyNode.Description: Wooden rattles used in Latin music. Usually played in pairs.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Maracas

TaxonomyNode.Description: A snare drum that is deeper than a normal snare drum and is carried by a sling or harness and marched with.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Snare Drum (Marching)

TaxonomyNode.Description: Tibetan finger cymbals used in Buddhist prayer and rituals. They are very thick, and they produce a unique, long sustaining tone.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tingsha

TaxonomyNode.Description: A snare drum without the snares.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tenor Drum

TaxonomyNode.Description: A Brazilian single-head drum. A stick attached to the head on the inside of the drum is rubbed to make a squeaking sound, and the other hand presses on the drum head to change the pitch.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Cuica

TaxonomyNode.Description: A Cameroonian instrument made out half of a dried Calabash fruit. The shell like dried fruit is struck with the hand and dragged across sticks to cause the shell to vibrate.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Calabash

TaxonomyNode.Description: The Bombo Criollo is a Latin American bass drum with skin heads that have fur still on them.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bombo

TaxonomyNode.Description: An African talking drum used by the Ghanaian Akan people. Typically played in pairs, the Atumpan (pl.) provide the bass part in Adowa dance ensembles.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Atumpan

TaxonomyNode.Description: A South Indian frame drum with a single or multiple tambourine jingles on the side.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Kanjira

TaxonomyNode.Description: A thin hollow instrument made from the cane-like trunk of a palm tree. Ridges are carved into the cane and it is played by dragging a metal brush across the ridges.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Guacharaca

TaxonomyNode.Description: A lathed and hammered disc of metal that is struck with a stick on the face of the cymbal.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Cymbal (Ride)

TaxonomyNode.Description: A Moroccan drum similar to a Darabuka.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Taarija

TaxonomyNode.Description: A Brazilian tambourine like frame drum.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Pandeiro

TaxonomyNode.Description: Two sticks clicked together. They produce a sound similar to claves. Used by the Aborigines.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Clapstick

TaxonomyNode.Description: A medium-sized, two-headed drum used in Brazilian Samba Baterias.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Repinique

TaxonomyNode.Description: A cylindrical piece of wood with washboard-like metal material wrapped around it, and strings of loose, moveable, metal beads wrapped around the corrugated metal material. Sound is produced when the beads are moved across the corrugated metal. The modern, metal cabasa was developed in the 1960s by Martin Cohen as a variation on traditional African instruments. Commonly used in Latin Music.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Cabasa

TaxonomyNode.Description: A small Brazilian frame drum of Portuguese and African origin. The instrument is played with a stick and has a very sharp sound.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tamborim

TaxonomyNode.Description: Various pitched bells, arranged one inside of another and mounted on a stand. A metal mallet is run across the bells to make a sweeping mystical sound.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bell Tree

TaxonomyNode.Description: A crank-operated gear plucks wooden tines that slap against the next ridge in the gear to make a clicking sound.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Ratchet

TaxonomyNode.Description: A medium-sized Middle Eastern frame drum with jingles.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Dayereh

TaxonomyNode.Description: Hand cymbals used by Tibetan monks in Buddhist rites. It has a broad central boss and is struck vertically.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Rolmo

TaxonomyNode.Description: Clap -- Clap - Clap - Clap your hands
TaxonomyNode.Name: Hand Claps

TaxonomyNode.Description: A metal sheet that makes a wobbly whoop noise when shaken. Invented by the Australian musician Rolf Harris and prominently featured in his 1960 novelty song, "Tie Me Kangaroo Down, Sport".
TaxonomyNode.Name: Wobble Board

TaxonomyNode.Description: *Stomp* - *Clap* - *Stomp*Stomp*Clap* Buddy you're a boy make a big noise…
TaxonomyNode.Name: Foot Stomp

TaxonomyNode.Description: Two lathed and hammered discs of metal that are struck against one another.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Cymbals

TaxonomyNode.Description: A single-headed, hourglass-shaped drum, with a high ringing pitch. It has ties to drums of many cultures across Africa, the Middle East, Europe, and Southeast Asia.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Doumbek

TaxonomyNode.Description: The metal ribbing of a washboard without a frame and hung around the neck. Played like a washboard, with spoon handles, bottle openers, or hands, by strumming, scratching, tapping, and rolling. Used in zydeco music.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Zydeco Rubboard

TaxonomyNode.Description: Instruments that produce sound from vibrating strings when the performer plays the strings in some manner, usually by bowing, plucking, or striking.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Strings

TaxonomyNode.Description: Produces sound by a bow being rubbed on the strings to create vibrations.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bowed Strings

TaxonomyNode.Description: A traditional Chinese dual-stringed instrument.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Banhu

TaxonomyNode.Description: A cello with gut strings and lower tension used during the baroque period.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Baroque Cello

TaxonomyNode.Description: A viola with gut strings and lower tension used during the baroque period.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Baroque Viola

TaxonomyNode.Description: A violin with gut strings and lower tension used during the baroque period.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Baroque Violin

TaxonomyNode.Description: An instrument similar to the viol, but with an extra set of plucked strings in addition to the bowed strings.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Baryton

TaxonomyNode.Description: The low variant of an ancient Middle Eastern fiddle instrument.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bass Rebec

TaxonomyNode.Description: A bass violin which is an ancestor to the modern cello.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Basso Da Braccio

TaxonomyNode.Description: A bowed lyre particularly associated with Welsh music and the medieval folk music of England.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Crwth

TaxonomyNode.Description: A fretted string instrument - a predecessor to the esraj. It resembles a combination of the sitar and sarangi.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Dilruba

TaxonomyNode.Description: A violin with two sets of strings on two separate fretboards attached by the body of the instrument.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Double Violin

TaxonomyNode.Description: A violin with six strings that is electric.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Electric 6-String Violin

TaxonomyNode.Description: A cello with an electric output and built in pickups.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Electric Cello

TaxonomyNode.Description: A viola with an electric output and built in pickups.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Electric Viola

TaxonomyNode.Description: A violin with an electric output and built in pickups.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Electric Violin

TaxonomyNode.Description: A Hurdy Gurdy with acoustic elements and electronic elements (pickups, EQ capabilities, etc.)
TaxonomyNode.Name: Electro-acoustic Hurdy Gurdy

TaxonomyNode.Description: A Chinese dual-stringed spike fiddle.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Erhu

TaxonomyNode.Description: A fretted string instrument descended from the dilruba. It resembles a combination of the sitar and sarangi.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Esraj

TaxonomyNode.Description: A folk term for the violin. Essentially synonymous with violin, but as "fiddle" generally refers to a folk instrument and not a highfalutin expensive orchestral thingy, the "fiddle" is sometimes smaller or more primitively constructed than a typical orchestral violin. Typically taught and played by ear, rather than with written music.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Fiddle

TaxonomyNode.Description: A traditional Bulgarian bowed lute with a nasally sound. It has three (sometimes four or five) main strings, and anywhere from zero to sixteen sympathetic resonating strings underneath those.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Gadulka

TaxonomyNode.Description: A Persian bowed lute with 4 or more strings.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Ghaychak

TaxonomyNode.Description: A traditional Norwegian fiddle. Unlike the standard violin, this instrument has eight or nine strings, thinner wood, and a flatter bridge.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Hardanger Fiddle

TaxonomyNode.Description: The Hurdy Gurdy is a stringed instrument that produces sound by a hand crank-turned, rosined wheel rubbing against the strings. The wheel functions much like a violin bow, and single notes played on the instrument sound similar to those of a violin.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Hurdy Gurdy

TaxonomyNode.Description: A Chinese bowed string instrument with 2 strings customarily tuned a 5th apart. The highest-pitched instrument in the huqin family. Unlike other members of the huqin family, the Jinghu is made of bamboo. Often used in Beijing opera.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Jinghu

TaxonomyNode.Description: A name used for various Mediterranean string instruments, usually with three strings. It is held upright with the butt end resting in the performer's lap.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Kemenche

TaxonomyNode.Description: The bass member of the lira family of fretted Renaissance string instruments with gut strings.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Lirone

TaxonomyNode.Description: A fiddle with a flat guitar-like body used in medieval times.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Medieval Fiddle

TaxonomyNode.Description: A small fiddle made from a gourd. Originating in Mali.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Njarka

TaxonomyNode.Description: A Nyckelharpa is a traditional Swedish musical instrument. It is a string instrument, or chordophone. Its keys are attached to tangents which, when a key is depressed, serve as frets to change the pitch of the string. Structurally, it is closely related to the hurdy-gurdy, with key-actuated tangents that are used to change the pitch.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Nyckelharpa

TaxonomyNode.Description: A early form of hurdy gurdy, dating from the late 10th or early 11th century. It consists of a wheel inside the body of an instrument, on which the strings rest, connected to a neck of wooden tangents, or keys, which change the pitch by tensioning the strings. Unlike later forms of hurdy-gurdy, the Organistrum was played by two people: one to turn the crank, and the other to pull the keys.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Organistrum

TaxonomyNode.Description: Phonofiddle is a class of stringed musical instruments that are played with a bow and use a phonograph type reproducer as a voice-box.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Phonofiddle

TaxonomyNode.Description: A Spanish folk fiddle that originated in the 12th century. Typically has two or three strings made of gut, steel, or twisted horse hair. Today, it is still used in the Spanish provinces of Cantabria and Asturias, as well as in parts of Latin America.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Rabel

TaxonomyNode.Description: A bowed string instrument that originated in the Middle East in the 8th century or earlier. It consists of a small, usually rounded body, the front of which is covered in a membrane and has a long neck with between 1 and 4 strings. A peg at the bottom allows it to be placed on the floor or any surface when being played. The instrument was spread throughout Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and the Far East along trade routes. Other "spike fiddles", such as the Chinese huqin, are generally considered to be descendants of the Rebab.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Rebab

TaxonomyNode.Description: A short-necked fiddle used in Hindustani classical music.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Sarangi

TaxonomyNode.Description: A two-stringed spike fiddle used in traditional Thai music.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Saw Duang

TaxonomyNode.Description: A violin fretboard attached to an aluminum diaphragm with an amplifying horn. It was used in the time when recordings were made with phonographs because a standard violin wasn’t loud enough to make a clean recording.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Strohl Violin

TaxonomyNode.Description: The second largest and second lowest-pitched Rebec
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tenor Rebec

TaxonomyNode.Description: A guitar and viol combined.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Togaman GuitarViol

TaxonomyNode.Description: The original version of a Rebec with five strings tuned in fifths. Tuned in the same range as a violin. It has a boat shaped body and was used in the medieval and Renaissance periods.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Treble Rebec

TaxonomyNode.Description: A seven-foot long, single-stringed instrument. The body of the instrument has a thin triangular cone shape. The instrument was used in medieval and Renaissance Europe.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tromba Marina

TaxonomyNode.Description: A European bowed stringed instrument used in the Medieval period, similar to a modern violin but with a somewhat longer and deeper body, three to five gut strings, and a leaf-shaped pegbox with frontal tuning pegs, sometimes with a figure-8 shaped body.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Vielle

TaxonomyNode.Description: A six-stringed instrument with a body similar to that a modern viola. There are multiple tunings of the viol which determines the instrument's range.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Viol

TaxonomyNode.Description: A particular tuning of the six or seven stringed Viola de Gamba or Viol. Alto tunings are (C3,F3,A3,D4,G4,C5) or (A2,D3,G3,B3,E4,A4)
TaxonomyNode.Name: Alto Viol

TaxonomyNode.Description: A particular tuning of the six or seven stringed Viola de Gamba or Viol. Bass tuning is (A1,D2,G2,C3,E3,A3,D4)
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bass Viol

TaxonomyNode.Description: A large viol with the tuning A1,D2,G2,B2,E3,A3.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Doublebass Viol

TaxonomyNode.Description: The smallest bass viol.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Lyra Viol

TaxonomyNode.Description: A particular tuning of the six or seven stringed Viola de Gamba or Viol. Tenor tuning is (G2,C3,F3,A3,D4,G4)
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tenor Viol

TaxonomyNode.Description: A particular tuning of the six or seven stringed Viola de Gamba or Viol. Treble tuning is (D3,G3,C4,E4,A4,D5)
TaxonomyNode.Name: Treble Viol

TaxonomyNode.Description: The viola d'amore is a 7- or 6-stringed musical instrument with sympathetic strings used chiefly in the baroque period.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Viola d'Amore

TaxonomyNode.Description: The viola pomposa is a five-stringed instrument developed around 1725. There are no exact dimensions applicable to all instruments used under this name, although in general the pomposa is slightly wider than a standard viola.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Viola Pomposa

TaxonomyNode.Description: A small violin tuned a minor third or a perfect fourth higher than a standard violin. The instrument was most popular during the Baroque period.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Violino Piccolo

TaxonomyNode.Description: A cross between a violin and guitar, it was essentially a fiberglass bodied electric violin with built-in distortion.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Vi-Tar

TaxonomyNode.Description: A long-necked Turkish lute with a round soundbox and a skin head similar to that of a banjo.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Yayli Tambur

TaxonomyNode.Description: A low-pitched Chinese spike fiddle.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Zhonghu

TaxonomyNode.Description: Traditional Korean bowed string instrument
TaxonomyNode.Name: Haegeum

TaxonomyNode.Description: Hit with a stick or metal spoon-like hammer to produce sound.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Hammered Strings

TaxonomyNode.Description: Large Eastern European hammered dulcimer.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Cimbalom

TaxonomyNode.Description: Dual-bridge, 29-string instrument with a trapezoidal sound board. The player holds a small, spoon-shaped mallet hammer in each hand to strike the strings.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Hammered Dulcimer

TaxonomyNode.Description: Southeast Asian hammered dulcimer derived from the Persian Santur.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Khim

TaxonomyNode.Description: Fretless zither played via a system of metal hammers. It features two octaves of double melody strings in the key of C major and four sets of chord strings (C major, G major, F major, and D7). Sounding somewhat like a mandolin, the Marxophone's timbre is also reminiscent of various types of hammered dulcimers.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Marxophone

TaxonomyNode.Description: Hammered dulcimer of Persian origin.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Santoor

TaxonomyNode.Description: Chinese hammered dulcimer.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Yangqin

TaxonomyNode.Description: Produces sound by a performer plucking its strings.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Plucked Strings

TaxonomyNode.Description: Lute instrument used in 17th century Europe that had a lower range than the tenor lute to extend into the range only previously achieved by the theorbo (a very large lute type instrument).
TaxonomyNode.Name: Arch Lute

TaxonomyNode.Description: Musical instrument in the chorded zither family. It features a series of chord bars attached to dampers, which, when pressed, mute all of the strings other than those that form the desired chord.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Autoharp

TaxonomyNode.Description: Long-necked lute originating in the Ottoman Empire.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Baglama

TaxonomyNode.Description: Russian stringed musical instrument with a characteristic triangular wooden, hollow body and three strings. Two strings are usually tuned to the same note and the third string is a perfect fourth higher.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Balalaika

TaxonomyNode.Description: Ukrainian folk instrument combining elements of the zither and lute. It has 5 to 12 strings.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bandura

TaxonomyNode.Description: Small, round-bodied Spanish folk instrument similar to the mandolin.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bandurria

TaxonomyNode.Description: Four, five, or six-stringed instrument with a thin membrane stretched over a frame or cavity as a resonator, called the head, which is typically circular.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Banjo

TaxonomyNode.Description: Banjo with five strings instead of the typical four. The fifth string is usually the same gauge as the first, but starts from the fifth fret, three quarters the length of the other strings. This lets the string be tuned to a higher open pitch than possible for the full-length strings.
TaxonomyNode.Name: 5-String Banjo

TaxonomyNode.Description: Six-string banjo with the standard tuning of a guitar.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Banjo Guitar

TaxonomyNode.Description: Short-neck banjo with the tuning of a mandolin.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Banjolin

TaxonomyNode.Description: There are many variants of bass banjos. They all have longer necks and a larger resonating drum than a regular banjo. Typical bass banjos are tuned to the same range as a cello.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bass Banjo

TaxonomyNode.Description: Another name for the bass banjo manufactured by S.S. Stewart with a lower range than a standard banjo and a 3" deep and 16" diameter rim.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Cello Banjo

TaxonomyNode.Description: Banjo with a shorter neck than a standard banjo, either with 17 or 19 frets. Even though it is called a tenor, its pitch is not lower than that of a normal banjo.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tenor Banjo

TaxonomyNode.Description: Japanese short-neck lute, often played to accompany narrative storytelling. Plucked with a large wooden pick.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Biwa

TaxonomyNode.Description: Greek string instrument with a pear-shaped body and a long, thin neck. Commonly used in Rebetiko music.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bouzouki

TaxonomyNode.Description: Turkish long-neck fretted lute. Used in Rahbani music.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bozoq

TaxonomyNode.Description: A type of bass ukulele.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bufo Bass

TaxonomyNode.Description: Small Portuguese guitar with four strings. Kind of like a standard guitar mixed with a ukulele.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Cavaquinho

TaxonomyNode.Description: Small five-stringed Andean instrument in the lute family.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Charango

TaxonomyNode.Description: One of the earliest plucked, necked instruments to appear in Europe.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Citole

TaxonomyNode.Description: Renaissance instrument, descended from the citole. Resembles a modern mandolin or bouzouki. Easier to play, smaller, less delicate and more portable than the lute.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Cittern

TaxonomyNode.Description: Larger, lower cittern.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bass Cittern

TaxonomyNode.Description: Guitar with an asymmetric body shape different than a standard guitar designed by Paulinho Nogueira. Its sound is similar to a Harpsichord.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Craviola

TaxonomyNode.Description: Small Puerto Rican/South American guitar that sounds similar to a mid-sized classical guitar, but it has a body shape similar to a viola.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Cuatro

TaxonomyNode.Description: Turkish instrument similar to an oud, but with an aluminum drum and head as a body like a banjo.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Cumbus

TaxonomyNode.Description: Vietnamese single-string zither.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Dan Bau

TaxonomyNode.Description: Vietnamese zither originating in the 13th or 14th century. Between 104 and 120 cm long and has 17 to 21 strings.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Dan Tranh

TaxonomyNode.Description: Long-necked lute from central Asian countries Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Turkmenistan, Afghanistan, and Mongolia.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Dombra

TaxonomyNode.Description: Small long-neck lute with a round body and three or four metal strings from Russia, Belarus, and Ukraine.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Domra

TaxonomyNode.Description: Small domra with a higher pitch than the standard domra.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Soprano Domra

TaxonomyNode.Description: Traditional Himalayan folk lute with six strings. It is used to accompany singing in the Drukpa Buddhist culture.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Dranyen

TaxonomyNode.Description: Traditional long-neck two-stringed lute from Iran and Central Asia.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Dutar

TaxonomyNode.Description: A combination of guitar, sitar, mandola, and gusli. Similar to a double-necked guitar.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Dzuddahord

TaxonomyNode.Description: One-string drone lute most often used in traditional music from Bangladesh, Egypt, India, and Pakistan.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Ektara

TaxonomyNode.Description: A type of zither that was developed and used only in the Vosges mountains in France.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Epinette des Vosges

TaxonomyNode.Description: Traditional Transylvanian instrument that has the appearance of a cello but has strings that are plucked or hit with sticks.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Gardon

TaxonomyNode.Description: Traditional Korean zither with 12 strings. Similar to the Dan Tranh.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Gayageum

TaxonomyNode.Description: Small lute with gut strings used in 13th century Europe.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Gittern

TaxonomyNode.Description: Seven-string Chinese zither.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Guqin

TaxonomyNode.Description: East Slavic string instrument of unknown origin. Similar to the Japanese koto, and believed to be derived from the ancient Greek lyre.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Gusli

TaxonomyNode.Description: 16 or 21-string Chinese zither that is 64 inches long.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Guzheng

TaxonomyNode.Description: Large, deep-bodied Mexican guitar-like instrument with 8 strings on 5 courses. It is usually used in a conjunto huasteco ensemble.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Huapanguera

TaxonomyNode.Description: Like a classic, 4-course Greek bouzouki, but with unison strings and a three-piece, partially staved back.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Irish Bouzouki

TaxonomyNode.Description: Thai three-string fretted zither that rests on the floor.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Jakhay

TaxonomyNode.Description: Small guitar-like instrument from the southern part of Veracruz Mexico with 8 strings in 5 courses.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Jarana Jarocha

TaxonomyNode.Description: Sudanese zither-like instrument used in Tembang Sunda, Mamaos Cianjuran, kacapi suling, pantun story recitation, or Gamelan Degung.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Kacapi

TaxonomyNode.Description: Finnish zither with 5-15 strings belonging to the Baltic box zither family of instruments.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Kantele

TaxonomyNode.Description: Large zither instrument used throughout the Middle East, west Africa, central Asia, and Southeastern Europe.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Kanun

TaxonomyNode.Description: Traditional Japanese instrument similar to the Chinese Zheng. They have 13 strings and 13 moveable bridges to change the tuning. The national instrument of Japan.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Koto

TaxonomyNode.Description: Norwegian drone zither with 8 drone strings.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Langeleik

TaxonomyNode.Description: Long-necked fretted lute from Greece and Cyprus, similar to the oud. It is played with a lone plectrum.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Laouto

TaxonomyNode.Description: Low-pitched, guitar-like instrument in the son jarocho string instrument family originating in Veracruz, Mexico.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Leona

TaxonomyNode.Description: Any plucked string instrument with a neck and a deep round back enclosing a hollow cavity.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Lute

TaxonomyNode.Description: Small harp used in Greek classical antiquity and later periods. The lyre is different from harps as it is actually a yoke lute because the strings are attached to a yok/soundbox and a crossbar.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Lyre

TaxonomyNode.Description: Small, guitar-like instrument in the lute family with 8 strings in 4 courses. Commonly played with a pick. Strings are tuned to the same pitches as a violin.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Mandolin

TaxonomyNode.Description: A mandolin with electric pickups.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Electric Mandolin

TaxonomyNode.Description: Baritone/bass member of the mandolin family, with four paired courses tuned C2, G2, D3, A3.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Mandocello

TaxonomyNode.Description: Tenor member of the mandolin family. Violin is to viola as mandolin is to mandola.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Mandola

TaxonomyNode.Description: Mandolin with nylon strings that has a sound between that of a mandolin and that of a ukulele.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Mandolele

TaxonomyNode.Description: Predecessor of the mandolin. Italian lute instruments with flat soundboards and gut strings.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Mandolino

TaxonomyNode.Description: Small French lute instrument originating in the late 16th century. Tuned in the treble range. Descendant of the gittern and also considered a predecessor of the modern mandolin.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Mandore

TaxonomyNode.Description: A name used to refer to two different instruments used in Hindustani music, either a modified sarod created by Radhika Mohan Maitra or a modified Hawaiian guitar created by Vishwa Mohan Bhatt.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Mohan Veena

TaxonomyNode.Description: South African instrument. A tight string attached to a curved stick. The string is struck with a thin stick while the performer's mouth is wrapped around the string creating different resonant formants. Another thicker stick is used to apply pressure to the string to change its pitch.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Musical Bow

TaxonomyNode.Description: Six-string instrument originating in West Africa. The instrument is made of wood or calabash with a dried animal skin head wrapped over it.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Ngoni

TaxonomyNode.Description: 5 to 8 string Kenyan lyre.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Nyatiti

TaxonomyNode.Description: Metal-stringed lute instrument from the Renaissance in the cittern family. It had a tilted nut and bridge to vary string length from the treble to the bass notes. A softer pluck was required to play the orpharion versus the lute because the metal strings had very low tension and could distort if plucked too hard.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Orpharion

TaxonomyNode.Description: Short-neck lute with a pear-shaped body. Used throughout the Middle East. It has 11 or 13 strings in 5 or 6 courses.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Oud

TaxonomyNode.Description: A type of ancient Greek lute or guitar used from the 3rd or 4th century B.C. and onward.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Pandura

TaxonomyNode.Description: Lute with a pear-shaped body originating in the Isan region of Thailand.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Phin

TaxonomyNode.Description: Four-string Chinese lute instrument with 12 to 26 frets.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Pipa

TaxonomyNode.Description: Fretted string instrument of the zither family, typically with three or four strings, originally played in the Appalachian region of the United States. The body extends the length of the fingerboard, and its fretting is generally diatonic.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Plucked Dulcimer

TaxonomyNode.Description: Present in numerous ancient cultures in the zither family either as a harp or a dulcimer-like instrument.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Psaltery

TaxonomyNode.Description: Bowed, 1 to 5-string instrument with a narrow, boat-shaped body. Used in the medieval and Renaissance eras.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Rebec

TaxonomyNode.Description: Indian 17 to 25-string lute instrument popularly used in Hindustani music. Has a deep, introspective sound.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Sarod

TaxonomyNode.Description: Three-string traditional Japanese musical instrument derived from the Chinese instrument sanxian. Played with a plectrum called a bachi.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Shamisen

TaxonomyNode.Description: Traditional lyre instrument used in Egypt, Jordan, and Yemen.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Simsimiyya

TaxonomyNode.Description: Three-string, skin-covered bass plucked lute. Used by the Gnawa people. It is approximately the size of a guitar, with a body carved from a log and covered on the playing side with camel skin. The camel skin has the same acoustic function as the membrane on a banjo. The neck is a simple stick with one short and two long goat strings that produce a percussive sound similar to a pizzicato cello or double bass.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Sintir

TaxonomyNode.Description: Indian instrument used in classical Hindustani music. Gets its unique sound from its sympathetic strings, bridge design, long neck, and gourd shaped resonant chamber. The sound is very rich in overtones.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Sitar

TaxonomyNode.Description: A bass sitar.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Surbahar

TaxonomyNode.Description: Harp-like zither instrument used in Hindustani music with 21 to 36 strings.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Swarmandal

TaxonomyNode.Description: Long-necked lute with 8 strings on 4 courses from Serbia, Macedonia, Croatia, and Bulgaria.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tambura

TaxonomyNode.Description: Long-necked Middle Eastern string instrument.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tanbour

TaxonomyNode.Description: Long-necked lute instrument used in many genres of music in the Indian subcontinent.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tanpura

TaxonomyNode.Description: Iranian long-necked, waisted instrument, shared by many cultures and countries including Iran, Azerbaijan, Armenia, Georgia, and others near the Caucasus region.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tar

TaxonomyNode.Description: Plucked string instrument of the lute family, with an extended neck and a second pegbox.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Theorbo

TaxonomyNode.Description: Five-string ukulele-like instrument from La Palma in the Canary Islands.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Timple

TaxonomyNode.Description: Traditional North Indian musical instrument from Punjab. The high-pitched, single-string instrument is associated with the folk music of Punjab and is presently very popular in Western Bhangra music.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tumbi

TaxonomyNode.Description: Greek lute instrument with 6 or 8 strings. It is very similar to the bouzouki.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tzouras

TaxonomyNode.Description: A member of the lute family of instruments. It generally employs four nylon or gut strings or four courses of strings. Some strings may be paired in courses, giving the instrument a total of six or eight strings.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Ukulele

TaxonomyNode.Description: Tube zither from Madagascar made from a species of local bamboo. Considered the national instrument of Madagascar.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Valiha

TaxonomyNode.Description: Ancient Indian lute instrument that developed into more modern Indian instruments.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Veena

TaxonomyNode.Description: Used in Hindustani music. It is similar to the Carnatic gottuvadhyam (chitra vina). It has no frets and is played with a slide.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Vichitra Veena

TaxonomyNode.Description: Guitar-shaped string instrument from 15th- and 16th-century Spain, Portugal and Italy, usually with five or six doubled strings.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Vihuela

TaxonomyNode.Description: Traditional West African lute with five strings.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Xalam

TaxonomyNode.Description: Small, 13-string Japanese plucked string instrument.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Yokin

TaxonomyNode.Description: Short-neck Chinese lute. Also referred to as a moon zither because of its round body shape.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Yueqin

TaxonomyNode.Description: Single or double-stringed instrument from Sub Saharan Africa. The strings are attached to a curved stick with a gourd attached to the stick as a resonator.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Zeze

TaxonomyNode.Description: A class of string instruments with many strings stretched across a thin flat body.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Zither

TaxonomyNode.Description: Largest and lowest pitched bowed string instrument in a modern orchestra. Deep and full-sounding.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Double Bass

TaxonomyNode.Description: Wooden string instrument in the violin family. Most violins have a hollow wooden body. Smallest and highest-pitched instrument in the family in regular use. Used in many styles of music, and capable of a wide variety of timbres and sounds, depending on the performance method.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Violin

TaxonomyNode.Description: String instrument that is bowed or played with varying techniques. It is slightly larger than a violin, and has a lower pitch and deeper sound. A standard orchestral instrument.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Viola

TaxonomyNode.Description: Four-string, fretless string instrument that is stood on the ground via a peg and held between the legs. Voicelike and with a warm, rich tone. The cello has a range of C2-C6.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Cello

TaxonomyNode.Description: Stringed musical instrument that has a number of individual strings running at an angle to its soundboard; the strings are plucked with the fingers.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Harp

TaxonomyNode.Description: A type of Sub-Saharan African Harp.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Ennanga

TaxonomyNode.Description: 21-string lute-bridge-harp used extensively in West Africa.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Kora

TaxonomyNode.Description: Ancient Chinese harp. Commonly used in court music during the Ming Dynasty, but went extinct until its revival in the 20th century as a double bridge harp. The revived version of the instrument does not resemble the ancient one, but is more similar to modern concert harps.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Kugo

TaxonomyNode.Description: An instrument that contains some type of resonator (usually a tube), in which a column of air is set into vibration by the player blowing into (or over) a mouthpiece set at or near the end of the resonator.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Wind

TaxonomyNode.Description: A very long natural horn with conical bore and a cup-shaped mouthpiece. Most often made of softwood - typically spruce, but sometimes pine. It was traditionally used by Western European mountain dwellers for communication, but is now primarily used as a musical instrument. The Alpenhorn has no pitch-altering devices and can only play notes in the harmonic series.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Alpenhorn

TaxonomyNode.Description: Also called the Tenor Horn, the Alto Horn is a conical bore saxhorn developed by Adolphe Sax in the 1840s. It is most commonly used in British brass bands, and it is similar to the French Horn in range and timbre.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Alto Horn

TaxonomyNode.Description: A low-pitched saxhorn with a conical bore. It is similar to the euphonium, but has a slightly lighter sound.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Baritone Horn

TaxonomyNode.Description: A small brass instrument with no pitch-altering devices. It is limited to the notes of the harmonic series. It is commonly used in the military.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bugle

TaxonomyNode.Description: An instrument made out of a conch shell, which naturally has a conical bore. It may be played unmodified, or a mouth hole be created by breaking off the point of the shell or by drilling a hole, and mouthpieces may even be inserted into the hole. Typically, no tone holes are drilled, and the conch is used as a natural horn.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Conch Shell

TaxonomyNode.Description: Similar to the trumpet, but has a conical bore and a mellower tone quality, and is more compact.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Cornet

TaxonomyNode.Description: Pitched in Eb, a perfect fourth higher than the standard Bb cornet.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Soprano Cornet

TaxonomyNode.Description: Timbrally deep and kaleidoscopic Indigenous Australian drone pipe. Generally 3 to 10 feet long, and can have either a cylindrical or conical bore. Traditionally played as accompaniment to ceremonial dancing and singing.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Didgeridoo

TaxonomyNode.Description: Also called the Tibetan Horn, the Dungchen is a long, straight, natural horn that is used in Tibetan and Mongolian Buddhist ceremonies.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Dungchen

TaxonomyNode.Description: Essentially a bass flugelhorn, the Fiscorn was formerly used in German and Czechoslovakian polka bands and Italian military bands, but is now most commonly played in Catalonian cobla bands.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Fiscorn

TaxonomyNode.Description: Similar to a trumpet, but with a wider, conical bore and a warmer sound.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Flugelhorn
