TaxonomyNode.Description: A valveless cylindrical brass instrument with a cupped mouthpiece. It was traditionally used to signal the arrival or departure of post riders and mail coaches.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Jagdhorn

TaxonomyNode.Description: A long natural horn historically played by Nordic and Germanic peoples.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Lur

TaxonomyNode.Description: A conical bore, middle-voiced brass instrument that is used in place of the French Horn in marching bands and drum and bugle corps, and occasionally to play French Horn parts in sitting ensembles.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Mellophone

TaxonomyNode.Description: An ancestor of the modern French horn, similar in appearance to it, but without any valves. Like other valveless brass instruments, the different notes of the harmonic series can be played, but in addition to that, the pitch can be changed by changing the position of the hand within the bell or by changing out crooks and thus changing the key.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Natural Horn

TaxonomyNode.Description: A keyed, conical bore brass instrument that was developed and used in the 19th century before eventually being superseded by the tuba.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Ophicleide

TaxonomyNode.Description: A valveless, cylindrical-bore natural horn with a cupped mouthpiece. Traditionally used to signal the arrival or departure of post riders and mail coaches.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Post Horn

TaxonomyNode.Description: An early kind of trombone that was in use primarily in the Renaissance and Baroque eras. It evolved from the slide trumpet, but unlike that instrument, it has a U-shaped slide with two parallel sliding tubes, which extends the range of the instrument down. Compared to modern trombones, the sackbut had a smaller, more cylindrically-proportioned bore and a less flared bell. It could play softly more easily than modern trombones.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Sackbut

TaxonomyNode.Description: The smallest sackbut, with the highest range.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Alto Sackbut

TaxonomyNode.Description: The largest sackbut, with the lowest range.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bass Sackbut

TaxonomyNode.Description: The middle-sized and middle range sackbut.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tenor Sackbut

TaxonomyNode.Description: Bass wind instrument made of wood, the pitch of which is controlled with side holes, and which is played with a mouthpiece like a brass instrument. It is considered a distant ancestor of the modern tuba. It was invented in the late 16th century and was commonly used in Europe until the 19th century.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Serpent

TaxonomyNode.Description: An ancient musical horn, typically made of a ram's horn, that is used for Jewish religious purposes.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Shofar

TaxonomyNode.Description: More or less a modified French Horn with a lower range that was originally created at the request of composer Richard Wagner for use in his Ring cycle.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Wagner Tuba

TaxonomyNode.Description: A trumpet made of wood rather than brass.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Wood Trumpet

TaxonomyNode.Description: Basque woodwind made up of a single reed, two small diameter melody pipes with finger holes, and a bell typically made from animal horn. The two pipes allow for simultaneous performance of two notes.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Alboka

TaxonomyNode.Description: Ancient Egyptian, single-reed, double-pipe woodwind. One pipe is longer and is a drone pipe, while the other one, the melodic pipe, is shorter and has several tone holes that change the pitch.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Arghul

TaxonomyNode.Description: Two soprano saxophones fused together that can be played separately or together at the same time by one player. It was developed by the Belgian François Louis and prototyped in 1999.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Aulochrome

TaxonomyNode.Description: Woodwind instrument which produces sound by enclosed reeds fed from a reservoir of air in a bag. Bagpipes are typically made up of several parts - the bag which holds air and regulates its flow, the chanter, which is a melody pipe with a reed at the top, played with two hands, and the drone, a pipe which is not fingered and which produces a constant drone. Though Scottish bagpipes are the most well-known, bagpipes were developed by 1000 BC by the ancient Hittites, and have historically been played across Europe, northern Africa, and western Asia.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bagpipes

TaxonomyNode.Description: Uncommon, large, low-pitched harmonica, often with two rows of reeds.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bass Harmonica

TaxonomyNode.Description: Mellow and open-sounding Chinese free reed, cylindrical-bore instrument with a single metal reed. It is played horizontally.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bawu

TaxonomyNode.Description: Conical-bore, double-reed woodwind used to play traditional Breton music. Member of the shawm family, and like most shawms, has a broad and powerful sound.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bombard

TaxonomyNode.Description: Smooth-sounding, voice-like, single-reed, cylindrical-bore woodwind folk instrument of the late Baroque and early Classical eras. Predecessor of the modern clarinet.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Chalumeau

TaxonomyNode.Description: Type of harmonica with a button-activated sliding bar that can adjust the pitch of each reed by a semitone when depressed, thus allowing the playing of the full chromatic scale.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Chromatic Harmonica

TaxonomyNode.Description: Sounds like an oboe had a baby with a saxophone. Capped reed (double reed mounted inside a long windcap, played by blowing through a slot in the windcap) instrument common in the Renaissance. The end is bent upwards in a long curve, and the instrument resembles the letter 'J'.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Crumhorn

TaxonomyNode.Description: Second highest crumhorn. There are Alto Crumhorns pitched in both G and in F, each with a typical range of a major ninth.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Alto Crumhorn

TaxonomyNode.Description: Highest-pitched crumhorn.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Soprano Crumhorn

TaxonomyNode.Description: Mid-range crumhorn, between the alto and bass in range.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tenor Crumhorn

TaxonomyNode.Description: Can describe two different instruments, both used in the Balkan nations of Serbia, Croatia and Montenegro. One is a double clarinet with two pipes bored in one piece of wood, each with its own reed. It can produce two notes at once. It was traditionally used by shepherds to signal each other, and is played at dances and weddings. The other Diple is a bagpipe which lacks a drone and instead has a double chanter with two separate single reeds.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Diple

TaxonomyNode.Description: Warm, soft, and nasally ancient Armenian double-reed woodwind made of apricot wood. It is commonly played in pairs, with one player playing a steady drone and the other playing the melody.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Duduk

TaxonomyNode.Description: Double-reed Renaissance woodwind with a folded conical bore. It was popular between 1550 and 1700, and is the predecessor of the modern bassoon.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Dulcian

TaxonomyNode.Description: Largest, lowest-pitched, and most common dulcian, pitched in F.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bass Dulcian

TaxonomyNode.Description: Smallest and highest-pitched dulcian.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Soprano Dulcian

TaxonomyNode.Description: Mid-range dulcian, between the alto and bass dulcians in range and size.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tenor Dulcian

TaxonomyNode.Description: North African double reed instrument. Nearly identical to the Turkish zurna and Arabic mizmar.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Ghaita

TaxonomyNode.Description: Mellow yet piercing Chinese cylindrical-bore, double-reed wind instrument, traditionally made from bamboo.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Guanzi

TaxonomyNode.Description: Brassy-sounding and piercing traditional Tibetan double-reed woodwind. It has a long hardwood body with 8 fingerholes and a copper brass bell. It is a part of the typical Tibetan ritual orchestra and is associated with devotion and peaceful deities.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Gyaling

TaxonomyNode.Description: Breathy, reedy, and timbrally expressive. The Harmonica is a small, hand-held, mouth-blown instrument made up of a series of free reeds, each with a fixed pitch.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Harmonica

TaxonomyNode.Description: Bagpipe native to Scotland. It is widely recognized due to its historic use in the British military and among piping bands. It consists of a bag, a chanter, a blowpipe, two tenor drones, and one bass drone.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Highland Pipes

TaxonomyNode.Description: Novelty instrument from the early 20th century, particularly known for being played by jazz musician Adrian Rollini. Essentially a miniature, primitive clarinet. It is bell-less, has tone holes which are covered directly by the fingers, and uses a miniature mouthpiece and an Eb clarinet reed.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Hot Fountain Pen

TaxonomyNode.Description: Clear and full-sounding Laotian mouth organ that is similar to the Chinese sheng. It has a free reed made of brass or silver encased in a small, hollowed-out, hardwood reservoir, which is connected to the pipes, which are most often made out of bamboo.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Khene

TaxonomyNode.Description: Miniature version of the khene, the Laotian mouth organ.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Miniature Khene

TaxonomyNode.Description: Buzzy and reedy Sardinian polyphonic woodwind instrument made of three pipes. One pipe drones as the other two play a melody in thirds and sixths.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Launeddas

TaxonomyNode.Description: Thin-sounding, small, mouth-powered, free-reed keyboard instrument. Popular in music education, but also embraced by professionals such as the dub reggae musician Augustus Pablo.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Melodica

TaxonomyNode.Description: Double-pipe, single-reed woodwind that is commonly played in the Levant as an accompaniment to belly dancing or dabke.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Mijwiz

TaxonomyNode.Description: Any single or double reed wind instrument in Arabic music. Typically similar to the Turkish zurna and Algerian ghaita.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Mizmar

TaxonomyNode.Description: Any mouth-played free reed aerophone with air chambers containing a free reed, such as the harmonica or sheng.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Mouth Organ

TaxonomyNode.Description: Reedy and smooth-sounding South Indian conical-bore double reed instrument. Used in the traditional classical music of Tamil Nadu, Andhra Pradesh, Karnataka and Kerala.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Nadaswaram

TaxonomyNode.Description: Generic term used for a variety of quadruple reed oboes used in traditional Thai music.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Pi

TaxonomyNode.Description: Clear, mellow, and reedy Indian wind instrument made up of a mouth-blow air reservoir (typically made out of a gourd) that channels air into two reedpipes. Commonly played by snake charmers.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Pungi

TaxonomyNode.Description: Renaissance-era double reed instrument that is small in size but which has a low range due to a folded bore. Mostly replaced by the bassoon by the end of the 17th century.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Rackett

TaxonomyNode.Description: Piercing, reedy, capped conical reed woodwind used in Europe in the 16th and 17th centuries. Very loud, and commonly used in outdoor performances in its day. Similar to the shawm.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Rauschpfeife

TaxonomyNode.Description: Small portable organ, furnished with beating reeds and having two bellows. Most widely used during the Renaissance.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Regal

TaxonomyNode.Description: Reedy and somewhat harsh-sounding family of single and double-reed woodwinds created by Pierre-Louis Gautrot in the mid-19th century to serve as a replacement for oboes and bassoons in outdoor wind bands. Sarrusophones had carrying power which oboes and bassoons of the time lacked. Now infrequently used as more of a novelty instrument in classical and jazz settings.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Sarrusophone

TaxonomyNode.Description: Large, low-pitched sarrusophone, pitched in Eb, an octave below the baritone sarrusophone.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Contrabass Sarrusophone

TaxonomyNode.Description: Reedy and clear-sounding conical-bore, double-reed woodwind that was common in Europe from 12th century up through the medieval and Renaissance periods, after which it was gradually replaced by the oboe family.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Shawm

TaxonomyNode.Description: Mid-range shawm, lower than the soprano and higher than the tenor.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Alto Shawm

TaxonomyNode.Description: Larger, lower-pitched shawm.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bass Shawm

TaxonomyNode.Description: Small, high-pitched shawm.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Soprano Shawm

TaxonomyNode.Description: Mid-range shawm, between the alto and bass shawms in range.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tenor Shawm

TaxonomyNode.Description: Reedy and smooth-sounding Indian double-reed instrument with a metal or wooden flared bell at the end. Commonly used in marriages, processions, and temples. Similar to the nadaswaram.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Shehnai

TaxonomyNode.Description: Clear and full-sounding polyphonic Chinese mouth organ. Consists of a series of pipes played by way of encased free reeds and a set of toneholes. Images depicting the Sheng date all the way back to 1100 BC.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Sheng

TaxonomyNode.Description: Japanese variant of the sheng, which was introduced to Japan in the 8th century. Tends to be slightly smaller than the sheng. Fundamental part of traditional gagaku music.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Sho

TaxonomyNode.Description: Deep and full-sounding Indian instrument powered by bellows (or powered electronically) which is used to provide drones.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Shruti Box

TaxonomyNode.Description: Family of cylindrical-bore, double-reed woodwinds that were used in the late 16th and early 17th centuries in Europe.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Sordun

TaxonomyNode.Description: Chinese double-reed instrument with a conical wooden body and a flared, detachable metal bell.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Suona

TaxonomyNode.Description: Refers to two distinct instruments, the newer of which was intended to be a recreation of the older, although they are essentially completely different instruments. The early Tárogató is a Hungarian instrument of Turkish origin, a type of shawm, with a double reed, conical bore, and no keys. It was commonly played as a signaling instrument in battle. The modern Tárogató was invented by Vencel József Schunda, a Hungarian instrument maker. It is a single-reed, conical-bore, keyed woodwind and it is commonly used in Hungarian and Romanian folk music.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tárogató

TaxonomyNode.Description: The characteristic bagpipe of Ireland. They are not blown - rather, the bag is inflated by a set of bellows that the player pumps with their elbow. Sweeter and quieter than many other kinds of bagpipe. A full set of Uilleann Pipes generally consists of bellows, a chanter, three drones - a tenor, a baritone, and a bass - as well as three regulators - a tenor, a baritone, and a bass - which provide harmonic accompaniment.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Uillean Pipes

TaxonomyNode.Description: Sounds mellow and reedy. Chromatic, keyless, cylindrical-bore, single-reed woodwind with a slightly flared bell that was developed by Brian Wittman in 1972.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Xaphoon

TaxonomyNode.Description: Made up of two parallel pipes, each with a single reed. On some instruments, both pipes have five or six holes, while on others, one pipe acts a drone.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Zummara

TaxonomyNode.Description: Penetrating and reedy central Eurasian, cylindrical-bore, double-reed woodwind typically made of the wood of fruit trees such as plum and apricot.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Zurna

TaxonomyNode.Description: Shrill and loud whistles which are typically played by Brazilian samba bandleaders.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Apito

TaxonomyNode.Description: Soft and woody-sounding Indian side blown flute made of bamboo. It is one of the most common instruments in Hindustani classical music.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bansuri

TaxonomyNode.Description: Approximates the sound of birdcall. Simple, hand-held, mouth-blown, and consists of a tube leading to a lip that splits the air stream.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bird Whistle

TaxonomyNode.Description: Shrill, loud, simple pipe or whistle used on ships by a boatswain to give commands. A tube directs air over a metal sphere with a hole in the top. Opening and closing a hand over the hole changes the pitch.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bosun's Whistle

TaxonomyNode.Description: Airy-sounding instrument which produces sound by sending steam or compressed air through large whistles. Often extremely loud, and there is no way to vary tone or loudness. Variants exist which can be controlled mechanically, by keyboard, and more recently, by MIDI. When steam power was commonly used, the Calliope was often used on riverboats and in circuses. It was originally patented by the American inventor Joshua C. Stoddard in 1855.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Calliope

TaxonomyNode.Description: Conical wooden pipe covered in leather, with finger holes and a small horn or ivory mouthpiece. It was popular from 1500 to 1650, and was commonly played in alta cappellas, or town wind bands in continental Europe.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Cornetto

TaxonomyNode.Description: Korean Bamboo Transverse Flute
TaxonomyNode.Name: Daegeum

TaxonomyNode.Description: Warm and airy Chinese transverse flute, typically made of bamboo.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Dizi

TaxonomyNode.Description: Shrill, small, high-pitched, transverse flute that originated in medieval Europe and which has been historically commonly used in military and marching bands.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Fife

TaxonomyNode.Description: Airy and delicate-sounding Catalan fipple flute commonly played in cobla bands.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Flabiol

TaxonomyNode.Description: Woody and bright fipple flute popular in Europe and America from the late 16th century to the early 20th century, particularly among amateur musicians.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Flageolet

TaxonomyNode.Description: Breathy, simple, end-blown bamboo flute used in Greek folk music.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Floyera

TaxonomyNode.Description: Deep, breathy, low-pitched, and large Slovakian fipple flute traditionally played by shepherds for recreation. It has only three tone holes, but the high aspect ratio of the sound chamber allows for playing of the diatonic scale by use of overtones.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Fujara

TaxonomyNode.Description: Breathy, dispersed-sounding flute that is widespread in Tunisia, Algeria, and Morocco.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Gasba

TaxonomyNode.Description: Mellow-sounding European ocarina, historically made from the horn of a chamois, goat, or other animal, and now more commonly made from cattle horns. They date at least back to the 15th century.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Gemshorn

TaxonomyNode.Description: A term used in the medieval period to refer to early European transverse flutes, used to differentiate them from end-blown flutes, which had been used for much longer in Europe.
TaxonomyNode.Name: German Flute

TaxonomyNode.Description: Clear-sounding, larger and lower-pitched tin whistle.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Irish Low Whistle

TaxonomyNode.Description: Breathy, dispersed-sounding end-blown flute traditionally played in Armenia, the Balkans, and Turkey.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Kaval

TaxonomyNode.Description: Breathy-sounding Thai vertical duct flute, typically made of bamboo.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Khlui

TaxonomyNode.Description: Romanian diatonic pan flute used since the 17th century.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Nai

TaxonomyNode.Description: Deep, breathy Middle Eastern end-blown flute that may be as much as 5000 years old. Traditionally made from a piece of hollow cane or giant reed, though modern ones may be made of metal or plastic.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Ney Flute

TaxonomyNode.Description: Clear-sounding vessel flute with four to twelve finger holes and a mouthpiece that extrudes from the body.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Ocarina

TaxonomyNode.Description: Ancient Chinese pan flute, with notches at the tops of the pipe holes that allow the pitch to be bent down a minor second.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Paixiao

TaxonomyNode.Description: End-blown instrument made of multiple pipes of gradually increasing length. Each pipe typically has a fixed pitch, and the player plays melodically by blowing from pipe to pipe.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Pan Flute

TaxonomyNode.Description: Andean end-blown duct flute played with one hand, often while the other hand plays a drum.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Pinkillu

TaxonomyNode.Description: Loud, shrill metal whistle historically used by (at least) English police.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Police Whistle

TaxonomyNode.Description: Dark-sounding traditional Andean end-blown flute.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Quena

TaxonomyNode.Description: Larger, lower-pitched quena.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Quenacho

TaxonomyNode.Description: Sounds clear and sweet. Prominent family of duct flutes in the Western classical tradition of music. Generally has seven finger holes for adjusting the pitch. Common from the medieval period up through the Baroque era, but fell out of favor after that. Often used in modern times as an educational instrument for children.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Recorder

TaxonomyNode.Description: Redesign of the recorder that came around in the late 17th century. Constructed in three separate pieces, with a fully chromatic range of two octaves to two octaves and a fifth.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Baroque Recorder

TaxonomyNode.Description: Large recorder in F, pitched an octave lower than the alto recorder.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bass Recorder

TaxonomyNode.Description: Large recorder that plays an octave lower than the ordinary bass recorder.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Contrabass Recorder

TaxonomyNode.Description: Refers either to the contrabass recorder in F, or to recorders pitched higher than that, in C and Bb.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Great Bass Recorder

TaxonomyNode.Description: Second-smallest and second-highest member of the recorder family.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Sopranino Recorder

TaxonomyNode.Description: Third-smallest and third-highest member of the recorder family.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Soprano Recorder

TaxonomyNode.Description: Tuned in C, an octave lower than the soprano recorder. Because of its larger size, the tenor recorder often has keys to make it easier to play the lowest notes.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tenor Recorder

TaxonomyNode.Description: Clear-sounding national instrument of Ecuador. A kind of pan flute in which the pipes are arranged pentatonically, so that a melody may be readily played in parallel thirds by a single player.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Rondador

TaxonomyNode.Description: Japanese end-blown flute, typically made of bamboo and tuned to the pentatonic scale. Mellow in its low tones, although it is equally capable of producing loud, penetrating and breathy tones in its middle and upper registers.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Shakuhachi

TaxonomyNode.Description: Inspired by the conch shell, designed to emulate whale songs.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Shelltone

TaxonomyNode.Description: Shrill, high-pitched Armenian fipple flute with a labium mouth piece.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Shvi Whistle

TaxonomyNode.Description: Traditional Andean pan pipe with two rows of pipes.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Siku

TaxonomyNode.Description: Simple tube with a piston inside and a fipple at the top. A slide plunger extends from the bottom, and is moved in and out, which produces a glissando effect.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Slide Whistle

TaxonomyNode.Description: Breathy, strong-sounding Southeast Asian bamboo ring flute. Used in gamelan orchestras.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Suling

TaxonomyNode.Description: Andean fipple flute with six finger holes, an angular shape, and a soft sound with a raspy low range.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tarka

TaxonomyNode.Description: Clear-sounding simple fipple flute with six tone holes. Commonly associated with Celtic music.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tin Whistle

TaxonomyNode.Description: Traditional Norwegian end-blown flute.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tusselfloyte

TaxonomyNode.Description: Nordic folk flute - a transverse fipple flute with no finger holes, on which the pitch is changed by covering or not covering the end and by varying the force of air blown into the flute.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Willow Flute

TaxonomyNode.Description: Any flute made of wood.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Wood Flute

TaxonomyNode.Description: Dispersed-sounding circular pan pipe played in Laos and Thailand and often used in Pong-Lang ensembles.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Wot

TaxonomyNode.Description: Mellow-sounding ancient Chinese end-blown flute, typically made of bamboo.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Xiao

TaxonomyNode.Description: Breathy and mellow-sounding ancient Chinese globular vessel flute, similar to an ocarina but without a fipple mouthpiece. It was initially made of baked clay or bone, and later came to also be made of clay or ceramic.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Xun

TaxonomyNode.Description: Member of the clarinet family, and like the clarinet, a single-reed woodwind with a cylindrical bore. However, the Basset Horn is larger than most clarinets, and has bends near the mouthpiece and the bell.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Basset Horn

TaxonomyNode.Description: Keyboard instrument which produces sound by blowing air through pipes or across reeds.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Organ

TaxonomyNode.Description: Keyboard instrument that produces sound by driving pressurized air through organ pipes. Each pipe has a fixed pitch. A Pipe Organ often contains multiple ranks of pipes with different timbres, pitches, and volumes that can be used in different combinations by use of stops.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Pipe Organ

TaxonomyNode.Description: Small pipe organ that is built to be easily portable. Common between the 10th and 18th centuries in chapels and small churches, as a chamber organ, and to play the basso continuo in ensembles.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Positive Organ

TaxonomyNode.Description: Electronic keyboard instrument derived from and originally intended to emulate the harmonium, pipe organ, and theater organ.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Electric Organ

TaxonomyNode.Description: Small inexpensive organs which make sound by air being forced over reeds by an electric fan.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bontempi

TaxonomyNode.Description: Small electric organ produced by the Italian manufacturer Farfisa.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Farfisa

TaxonomyNode.Description: Electric organ with two hand-played keyboards and a foot-controlled bass keyboard. Hammonds have drawbars which can be pushed and pulled in and out to additively synthesize a variety of timbres. Released in 1935, the Hammond was the first popular electric organ. It was originally marketed as a budget substitute for pipe organs, but soon took on a life of its own, particularly as a common and fundamental instrument in gospel, blues, jazz, and rock music. Commonly played with a rotating Leslie speaker cabinet, which, depending on the speed of rotation, can create either a chorus or vibrato effect.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Hammond

TaxonomyNode.Description: Produced from 1949 to 1954. An electric organ with two hand-played keyboards and a foot-controlled bass keyboard. Hammonds have drawbars which can be pushed and pulled in and out to additively synthesize a variety of timbres. It was originally marketed as a budget substitute for pipe organs, but soon took on a life of its own, particularly as a common and fundamental instrument in gospel, blues, jazz, and rock music. Commonly played with a rotating Leslie speaker cabinet, which, depending on the speed of rotation, can create either a chorus or vibrato effect. Has a deeper cabinet than earlier models, as well as variable vibrato.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Hammond B3

TaxonomyNode.Description: Produced from 1954 to 1974. An electric organ with two hand-played keyboards and a foot-controlled bass keyboard. Hammonds have drawbars which can be pushed and pulled in and out to additively synthesize a variety of timbres. It was originally marketed as a budget substitute for pipe organs, but soon took on a life of its own, particularly as a common and fundamental instrument in gospel, blues, jazz, and rock music. Commonly played with a rotating Leslie speaker cabinet, which, depending on the speed of rotation, can create either a chorus or vibrato effect. Like the B2, it has a deeper cabinet than earlier models, as well as variable vibrato. It also has an added harmonic percussion circuit.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Hammond C3

TaxonomyNode.Description: Electric organ invented by Frederick Lowrey. It was the most popular organ in the world during the 1960s and 1970s. It is primarily differentiated from its precursor, the Hammond organ, by its "automatic accompaniment" features, such as the preset drum patterns which can be heard on Timmy Thomas's "Why Can't We Live Together", and subsequently on Drake's "Hotline Bling", which samples that song. Like the Hammond, the Lowrey is an electric organ with two hand-played keyboards and a foot-controlled bass keyboard. Lowreys have drawbars which can be pushed and pulled in and out to additively synthesize a variety of timbres.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Lowrey

TaxonomyNode.Description: Introduced in 1962, the Vox Continental is a transistorized combo organ with a bright, breathy sound. It was intended as a touring replacement of heavier tonewheel organs, such as the Hammond B3. It is prominently featured in many major rock recordings, such "The House of the Rising Sun" by The Animals, "Light My Fire" by The Doors, and "I'm a Believer" by The Monkees.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Vox Continental

TaxonomyNode.Description: Electric organ produced by Wurlitzer.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Wurlitzer Electric Organ

TaxonomyNode.Description: A type of free-reed organ that creates sound as air flows past a framed, vibrating piece of thin metal. It was intended to be a smaller, portable version of a pipe organ, and was widely used in small churches and private homes in the 19th century.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Pump Organ

TaxonomyNode.Description: Family of box-shaped bellows-driven free-reed aerophones. Played by compressing or expanding the bellows while pressing buttons or keys, causing pallets to open, which allow air to flow across strips of brass or steel called reeds. These vibrate to produce sound inside the body. Valves on opposing reeds of each note are used to make the instrument's reeds sound louder without air leaking from each reed block. The performer normally plays the melody on buttons or keys on the right-hand manual, and the accompaniment, consisting of bass and pre-set chord buttons, on the left-hand manual.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Accordion

TaxonomyNode.Description: Accordion with buttons, rather than keys, arranged chromatically, rather than diatonically.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Chromatic Button Accordion

TaxonomyNode.Description: Accordion with a right-hand keyboard similar to a piano or organ keyboard.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Piano Accordion

TaxonomyNode.Description: Type of concertina (a free-reed instrument made of expanding and contracting bellows with buttons or keys on both ends) that is especially popular in Argentina and Uruguay. It has been a mainstay of tango ensembles since the 1910s. It was developed by the German instrument dealer Heinrich Band in the early 18th century, was introduced to Argentina and Uruguay by German and Italian immigrants in the late 19th century, and has historically been produced primarily in Germany.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bandoneon

TaxonomyNode.Description: Small accordion designed for children, typically with a single octave of diatonic buttons.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Toy Accordion

TaxonomyNode.Description: Chromatic, bellows-blown bagpipe that was popular in French court and art music in the Baroque era.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Musette

TaxonomyNode.Description: Free-reed musical instrument made up of expanding and contracting bellows with buttons or keys on both ends. It was developed in England and Germany in the early 19th century.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Concertina

TaxonomyNode.Description: Button accordion on which the melody-side keyboard contains one or more rows of buttons with each row producing the notes of a diatonic scale. The bass side of the keyboard has fewer buttons, arranged in pairs, with one button of each pair playing the root of a chord and the other the corresponding major or minor triad.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Melodeon

TaxonomyNode.Description: Line of electronic accordions produced in the mid-20th century.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Cordovox

TaxonomyNode.Description: Weird instruments - the kind of stuff you see in a pawn shop and wonder what the heck it's for.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Other

TaxonomyNode.Description: Mechanical musical instrument consisting of bellows and one or more ranks of pipes housed in a case, usually of wood, and often highly decorated. The basic principle is the same as a traditional pipe organ, but rather than being played by an organist, the barrel organ is activated either by a person turning a crank, or by clockwork driven by weights or springs. Pieces of music are encoded onto wooden barrels (or cylinders), which are analogous to the keyboard of the traditional pipe organ. A person (or in some cases, a trained animal) which plays a barrel organ is known as an organ grinder.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Barrel Organ

TaxonomyNode.Description: A bicycle pump - a performer puts their finger over the valve to produce squeaky sounds from pumping.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bicycle Pump

TaxonomyNode.Description: A comb with a piece of tissue paper placed around it. Air is passed through it and the paper vibrates like a kazoo.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Comb

TaxonomyNode.Description: Very old personal audio recorder produced by Alexander Graham Bell, sometimes used to record music for its distinctive grainy quality.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Dictaphone

TaxonomyNode.Description: Small electronic kalimba held like a guitar.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Hohner Guitaret

TaxonomyNode.Description: Small metal instrument placed in the performer's mouth. A piece of metal is plucked with the finger and the pitch and harmonic content of the sound is shaped with the mouth.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Jew's Harp

TaxonomyNode.Description: An instrument that is sung into. A small piece of paper in the instrument adds a buzzing quality to the sung pitch.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Kazoo

TaxonomyNode.Description: Crank-operated instrument with a rotating metal cylinder. The metal cylinder has small bumps that pluck metal tines as the cylinder rotates.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Music Box

TaxonomyNode.Description: Electronic instrument with buttons to select pitch and chord quality. When the buttons are pressed, the selected chord is produced.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Omnichord

TaxonomyNode.Description: The moving back and forth of a vinyl record on a turntable for a high-pitched scrubbing or scratching sound. Common performance style among early hip-hop DJs.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Turntable Scratching

TaxonomyNode.Description: Synthesizer that can load up audio recordings, or samples, which can then be programmed or performed on the synthesizer.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Sample Sequencer

TaxonomyNode.Description: Sampler produced by Akai beginning in 2003. It features their distinctive pressure sensitive pads.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Akai MPC-1000

TaxonomyNode.Description: One of the first professional-quality 16-bit stereo samplers. Produced by Akai from 1988 to 1933.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Akai S1000

TaxonomyNode.Description: Keyboard-based digital synthesizer and sampler initially produced by Fairlight from 1979 to 1989.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Fairlight CMI

TaxonomyNode.Description: Popular software synthesizer and sampler produced by Los Angeles-based Spectrasonics.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Spectrasonics Omnisphere

TaxonomyNode.Description: Small synthesizer and sequencer released by Yamaha in 1997.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Yamaha QY70

TaxonomyNode.Description: Small piano meant to be played by children, with sound produced by small pitched metal rods instead of strings.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Toy Piano

TaxonomyNode.Description: A software or hardware effect unit which creates a discrete number of repetitions of varying intensity with a determinite time in between each repetition.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Delay

TaxonomyNode.Description: The absence of reverb.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Dry

TaxonomyNode.Description: "Technical flaws" such as distortion, hum, backgroud noise, and limited bit depth create a "low-fidelity" aesthetic.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Lo-Fi

TaxonomyNode.Description: Short sections of previously recorded sound repeated continuously
TaxonomyNode.Name: Looping

TaxonomyNode.Description: A gradual pitch modulation effect or slide
TaxonomyNode.Name: Portamento

TaxonomyNode.Description: An audio sample is mirrored and played backwards
TaxonomyNode.Name: Reverse

TaxonomyNode.Description: The create use of an extract of an existing recording.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Sampling

TaxonomyNode.Description: A trembling effect that is a variation in volume
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tremolo

TaxonomyNode.Description: A steady increase and decrease in the frequency sweet of a low pass filter, creating a "wah-wah" sound. Can also be done using a plunger on a trumpet or trombone
TaxonomyNode.Name: Wah

TaxonomyNode.Description: Technique describes the execution of either an approach to an instrumental or production aesthetic.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Instrument Technique

TaxonomyNode.Description: An instruction for string players to strike the string with the wood side of the bow, not the hair
TaxonomyNode.Name: Col legno

TaxonomyNode.Description: Bowing slightly over the fingerboard to produce a "flutelike" sound effect
TaxonomyNode.Name: Flautando

TaxonomyNode.Description: An ascending or descending glide that explicitly articulates the transition from one pitch to another.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Glissando

TaxonomyNode.Description: A tone produced on a stringed instrument by lightly touching an open or stopped vibrating string at a given fraction of its length so that both segments vibrate
TaxonomyNode.Name: Harmonics

TaxonomyNode.Description: Smooth and connected transition between notes.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Legato

TaxonomyNode.Description: Instruction for a note, chord, or passage to be played louder or more forcefully
TaxonomyNode.Name: Marcato

TaxonomyNode.Description: A "hammered" bowstroke produced by holding the bow against the string with pressure, then stroked forcefully to produce an intense note
TaxonomyNode.Name: Martele

TaxonomyNode.Description: Pushing more air than needed through a Wind instrument to create a harsh, more forced sound.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Overblown

TaxonomyNode.Description: Plucking the strings of a string instrument with one's finger
TaxonomyNode.Name: Pizzicato

TaxonomyNode.Description: Notes are played "moderately detached", and is considered playing between staccato and legato
TaxonomyNode.Name: Portato

TaxonomyNode.Description: The throw or drop of the bow setting off a series of two or more successive notes as the bow naturally rebounds and hits the string again
TaxonomyNode.Name: Ricochet

TaxonomyNode.Description: A fast, bouncing or springing stroke in which the bow naturally bounces off the string producing a lighter, more rapid and less percussive sound than spiccato
TaxonomyNode.Name: Sautille

TaxonomyNode.Description: Bowing technique in which the bow bounces lightly upon the string
TaxonomyNode.Name: Spiccato

TaxonomyNode.Description: An articulation on a note making it shortened, pointed and precise.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Staccato

TaxonomyNode.Description: Instruction to string player to bow or pluck very close to the bridge
TaxonomyNode.Name: Sul ponticello

TaxonomyNode.Description: A musical ornamentation which requires rapid alternation between two notes
TaxonomyNode.Name: Trill

TaxonomyNode.Description: A pulsating effect in an instrumental tone produced by slight and rapid variations in pitch
TaxonomyNode.Name: Vibrato

TaxonomyNode.Description: A distorted guitar technique using a light palm mute while using a pick to rapidly down stroke repeatedly
TaxonomyNode.Name: Chugging

TaxonomyNode.Description: A hand-held electronic device for the electric guitar which uses an electromagnetic field to move the strings creating a sound reminiscent of using a bow
TaxonomyNode.Name: E-bow

TaxonomyNode.Description: Plucking the strings directly with the fingertips, fingernails, or picks attached to the fingers
TaxonomyNode.Name: Fingerstyle

TaxonomyNode.Description: Repeated attack of chords on a piano played vigorously
TaxonomyNode.Name: Hammering

TaxonomyNode.Description: Usually performed on a fretted string instrument, a fretting-hand finger is sharply brought down on the fingerboard behind the fret, causing a note to sound
TaxonomyNode.Name: Hammer-on

TaxonomyNode.Description: Placing the picking hand on top of the strings and next to the bridge while picking of a plectrum-based string instrument, creates a dampened sound.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Palm muting

TaxonomyNode.Description: A technique used on string instruments using a pick to pluck the string instead of the fingers, giving a sharper attack and sound
TaxonomyNode.Name: Picking

TaxonomyNode.Description: Strings of an electric or double bass are plucked and released so as to vibrate sharply against the fretboard or fingerboard
TaxonomyNode.Name: Slapping

TaxonomyNode.Description: The use of a slide on a guitar, bass, dobro, or pedal steel to create a seamless transition between notes
TaxonomyNode.Name: Slide

TaxonomyNode.Description: A sweeping action where a thumb, fingernail or pick brushes multiple strings to produce a chord
TaxonomyNode.Name: Strumming

TaxonomyNode.Description: Sounds made by (non-human) animals.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Animal Sounds

TaxonomyNode.Description: Cheering or clapping from a crowd.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Applause

TaxonomyNode.Description: Car alarms, beeping, car doors, cars driving, cars crashing, tires screeching, car radio, etc.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Car Sounds

TaxonomyNode.Description: Background talking noise from a party or crowd environment.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Chatter

TaxonomyNode.Description: Mouth noise of chewing food or other objects. *Om nom nom*
TaxonomyNode.Name: Chewing Sounds

TaxonomyNode.Description: An effects device for electric guitar that gives the guitar a shimmery, synth pad-like sound. Created prior to the advent of the polyphonic synthesizer by members of the British rock group 10cc in 1969 to add more texture to their music on the cheap. Listen to it on "Old Wild Men" by 10cc.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Gizmo

TaxonomyNode.Description: The sound of guns firing. *DOOT DOOT DOOT* *BANG BANG*
TaxonomyNode.Name: Gunshots

TaxonomyNode.Description: Cutting, splicing, or otherwise manipulating analog magnetic tape with sound recorded to it. Frequently done by early electronic music pioneers, such as the musique concrète composer Pierre Schaeffer. Listen to his and Pierre Henry's Orphée 53.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Magnetic Tape Treatments

TaxonomyNode.Description: A short single note with sharp attack that sounds like an entire orchestra playing at once.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Orchestral Hit

TaxonomyNode.Description: Police siren, ambulance, fire truck, emergency siren, etc. *wee-ooh wee-ooh*
TaxonomyNode.Name: Siren

TaxonomyNode.Description: Train horns. Chugga Chugga Choo Choo noises.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Train Sounds

TaxonomyNode.Description: Static, clicks, pops and other noises that come from the degradation of old recording masters, as well as from the editing or manipulation of sound.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Unintended Artifacts

TaxonomyNode.Description: A person who performs a musical work.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Performer

TaxonomyNode.Description: The energy level presented through music by the performer.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Intensity

TaxonomyNode.Description: Voice describes Vocal qualities including Arrangement, Gender, Technique, Accompaniment, Delivery and Effects.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Voice

TaxonomyNode.Description: The main vocal performer on a song recording.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Lead Vocals

TaxonomyNode.Description: Boy Voice.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Boy

TaxonomyNode.Description: Child's Voice, male or female.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Child

TaxonomyNode.Description: Female Voice.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Female

TaxonomyNode.Description: Girl Voice.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Girl

TaxonomyNode.Description: Male Voice.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Male

TaxonomyNode.Description: Multiple Voice Genders and/or Ages.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Mixed

TaxonomyNode.Description: Indeterminate Voice Gender.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Neutral

TaxonomyNode.Description: One or multiple vocalists that perform in harmony or in a call and response arrangement with the lead vocalist on a song recording.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Background Vocals

TaxonomyNode.Description: 1-3 Child Voices supporting the featured Voice.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Child Backgrounds

TaxonomyNode.Description: 1-3 Female Voices supporting the featured Voice.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Female Backgrounds

TaxonomyNode.Description: 1-3 Male Voices supporting the featured Voice.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Male Backgrounds

TaxonomyNode.Description: 1-3 Voices supporting the featured Voice, Multiple Voice Genders and/or Ages.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Mixed Backgrounds

TaxonomyNode.Description: Various kinds of choir and vocal group.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Vocal Ensemble

TaxonomyNode.Description: >11 vocal performers
TaxonomyNode.Name: Choir

TaxonomyNode.Description: 10-30 Child Voices.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Childrens Choir

TaxonomyNode.Description: 10-30 Female Voices.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Female Choir

TaxonomyNode.Description: 10-30 Male Voices.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Male Choir

TaxonomyNode.Description: 10-30 Voices. Multiple Voice Genders and/or Ages.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Mixed Choir

TaxonomyNode.Description: Two featured Solo Voices in featured conversation.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Vocal Duet

TaxonomyNode.Description: Two or more Voices, Voice Arrangements or Voice Ensembles presented in isolated conversation by section.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Alternating

TaxonomyNode.Description: Speaking or singing of words or sounds.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Chant

TaxonomyNode.Description: Two Voices singing in perfect unison.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Double

TaxonomyNode.Description: Style of background vocals where a large group of people sing or shout the lyrics in sloppy unison.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Gang Vocals

TaxonomyNode.Description: Two or more Voices singing in conversation, creating two distinct phrases where the second is a direct commentary on the first.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Question And Answer

TaxonomyNode.Description: An effect used to modulate pitch in vocal performances.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Autotune

TaxonomyNode.Description: A set number of Vocal repetitions with a determinate time in between each repetition
TaxonomyNode.Name: Delay

TaxonomyNode.Description: Controlled by lip-syncing or changing mouth shape, it imposes speech sounds onto a musical instrument, typically a guitar, via a vocal tube and effects pedal.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Talkbox

TaxonomyNode.Description: A synthesizer that produces sounds from an analysis of speech input.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Vocoder

TaxonomyNode.Description: An effect that alters the natural sound of the Voice.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Voice Effects

TaxonomyNode.Description: A short clip of an original vocal Recording.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Voice Sample

TaxonomyNode.Description: I’m at $500 n I wan $550, $550, bid on $550, I’m at $500 would you go $550, $550 …
TaxonomyNode.Name: Auctioneer

TaxonomyNode.Description: Vocal percussion that emulates drum beats, turntable or sound effects, musical sounds and rhythms.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Beatbox

TaxonomyNode.Description: The sound of inhaling and exhaling.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Breathing

TaxonomyNode.Description: The high-pitched and breathy Vocal range above the chest register.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Falsetto

TaxonomyNode.Description: Singing with the lips closed and without articulation
TaxonomyNode.Name: Hum

TaxonomyNode.Description: hahahaha.... HAHAHAHA.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Laughter

TaxonomyNode.Description: A continuous string of notes sung to one syllable of text
TaxonomyNode.Name: Melisma

TaxonomyNode.Description: Spoken, Rhythmic Lyric.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Rap

TaxonomyNode.Description: Scoby-doaby doo waaaaaaaaa we ah…. Doh be doh be dwoo dwaa…
TaxonomyNode.Name: Scat

TaxonomyNode.Description: Loud, piercing, shrieking cries; sung or spoken.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Scream

TaxonomyNode.Description: A mix of singing and talking almost exclusively found in Reggae music.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Sing-Jay

TaxonomyNode.Description: Onomatopoeic, Indian drum syllable language (i.e. Dha Ge Te, Dha Ge Te, Dha)
TaxonomyNode.Name: Konnakol

TaxonomyNode.Description: Conversation-like speech, no rhythmic or melodic elements.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Spoken

TaxonomyNode.Description: A mixture of talking and singing with emphasis on the talking against the Voice melody's rhythmic elements.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Talk-Sing

TaxonomyNode.Description: A oscillating effect in a Voice produced by slight and rapid variations in pitch.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Vibrato

TaxonomyNode.Description: Sounds like the dry groggy voice when you just wake up. The vocal fry register is the lowest vocal register and is produced through a loose glottal closure that permits air to bubble through slowly with a popping or rattling sound of a very low frequency.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Vocal Fry

TaxonomyNode.Description: Singing with such force that the vocal chords are strained, producing a scratchy, hoarse, harsher tone.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Vocal Strain

TaxonomyNode.Description: Style of Jazz singing where words are given to the melodies and solos of previously instrumental compositions.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Vocalese

TaxonomyNode.Description: Using the breath, rather than the throat, in a very hushed and quiet tone.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Whisper

TaxonomyNode.Description: A clear, high-pitched sound made by forcing breath through a small hole between partially closed lips of the teeth.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Whistle

TaxonomyNode.Description: Rapid and repeated melodic-alternating from a fundamental chest pitch, to a higher falsetto/head register pitch, generates a high-low-high-low sound.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Yodel

TaxonomyNode.Description: Talking or chanting, usually in a monotone melody, over a rhythm or beat by a deejay in Reggae or Dancehall music.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Toasting

TaxonomyNode.Description: The highest register of the human voice, lying above the modal register and falsetto register. This register has a specific physiological production that is different from the other registers, and is so called because the timbre of the notes that are produced from this register is similar to that of a whistle.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Whistle Register

TaxonomyNode.Description: Lyrical subjects, moods, and techniques.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Lyrics

TaxonomyNode.Description: Where/when did it come from?
TaxonomyNode.Name: Origin

TaxonomyNode.Description: Any location relevant to the music
TaxonomyNode.Name: Relevant Location

TaxonomyNode.Description: Sonic-cultural groupings of music.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Genre

TaxonomyNode.Description: Characterized by a loose narrative lyrical style, use of call-and-response, the blues scale and blue notes, a small set of common chord progressions, and trance-like walking basslines. Originated in African-American communities in the Deep South of the United States in the late 19th century.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Blues

TaxonomyNode.Description: The 1920s was witness to a Black workers' emigration from life on the Delta; Black workers left behind rural plantation life and headed into urban centers, North, West and East, which promised a higher quality of life. Both this urbanization, which shifted the geographical focus of blues away from its traditional Southern Roots, and the invention of the electric guitar (which had gained popularity in the Jazz Big Bands of 1930s) gave birth to the adoption of the electric guitar into Blues. Early Traditional Electric Blues traces include West Coast Blues guitarist T-Bone Walker (originally form Texas), who began experimenting with the electric guitar in the mid 1930s in Los Angeles. While in the 1940s, in Memphis, Memphis Minnie, Muddy Waters and Arthur "Big Boy" Crudup in Chicago, in Texas, Sam "Lightnin Hopkins and in Detroit, John Lee Hooker. Through the 1950s-1970s, Traditional Electric Blues paved the way for other genres including Rock N' Roll, R&B, Soul and Classic Rock many artists of which continued to expand the aesthetic potential of the Blues by applying more contemporary instrumentation to it, all the while upholding the essential components of Blues music in their compositions. Electric blues is a type of Traditional Blues music distinguished by the amplification of the guitar, bass guitar and often the harmonica.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Traditional Electric

TaxonomyNode.Description: Blues came from over a hundred-year-evolving juxtaposition of the musical and cultural traditions of Africa (i.e. African American slaves) and Europe. Traditional Blues represent the structural and cultural genesis of blues, a genre that manifested an array of African-American cultural experience (i.e. spirituals to work songs to field hollers) into a three-phrase lyrical prose aligned within a 12-bar song structure. The 12-bar blues song-form is musically identified by a thematic, three-chord progression which uses the tonic, sub-dominant and dominant chords of the scale and a melodically alternating, bended 'blue note': a lowered third scale degree (or mediant), which alternates with frequent improvisation, between its natural third scale degree. Rooted in the traditions of the Deep South and also known as Country Blues, Traditional Acoustic Blues is primarily minimal in instrumentation (i.e. a vocalist accompanied by an acoustic guitar) and lyric themes tend to focus on hardship and sorrow.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Traditional Acoustic

TaxonomyNode.Description: Traditional Western art music. Though wide-ranging in sound and style, it is largely characterized by its system of staff notation, and often by its musical complexity.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Classical

TaxonomyNode.Description: Western music from approximately 500 to 1400. Medieval music ranges from monophonic chants to highly complex and layered rhythmical and melodic concoctions. Early Medieval music was learned by ear, but it was in the Medieval era that musical notation made significant developments, first in showing general melodic direction, and later, by way of the innovation of the musical staff, the ability to show more exact musical pitch intervals and the subsequent capability of non-oral transmission of melodies. Rhythmic notation began to develop in the Medieval era as well, opening up new musical possibilities which composers gladly exploited.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Medieval

TaxonomyNode.Description: Western music from roughly 1400 to 1600. Secular and sacred music were both common, made possible by massive advances in musical notation and the development of the printing press, which allowed for easier copying of musical notation. Polyphony flourished in the Renaissance period. Triads began to appear in the 15th century, and in the 16th century, the harmonic system of church modes was gradually replaced by the concept of functional tonality. Opera was developed in the Renaissance, along with early versions of many modern instruments.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Renaissance

TaxonomyNode.Description: Western art music composed from approximately 1580 to 1760. Common-practice tonality began to emerge in the Baroque era, moving from the Renaissance era focus on independent melodic lines toward a key-centric view of tonality and an emphasis on formal separation of bass, melody, and accompaniment. Baroque music often features elaborate musical ornamentation and looser implied rules regarding counterpoint and dissonance than Renaissance music. Western musical groups and forms expanded in size, range, complexity and variety during the Baroque era - forms such as the opera, cantata, oratorio, solo concerto, sonata, and fugue emerged during this time. In contrast to later Classical eras, Baroque performers were often skilled improvisers of melodic lines and accompaniment, and improvisation and ornamentation were fundamental elements of many Baroque performances. The Baroque era saw the increasing preeminence of instruments and instrumental forms - composers began to write for specific instruments and instrumental ensembles with texture in mind, as opposed to the earlier Renaissance focus on vocal music and the limitation of instrumental music largely to transcriptions of vocal music.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Baroque

TaxonomyNode.Description: Romantic music consists of Western art music written approximately from the late 18th century to the early 20th century. Romantic music, compared to music of the preceding Classical period, was more expressive, dynamic, and programmatic. The size of the orchestra increased as its internal makeup diversified. Melodies became longer and more fluid, harmonic progressions became more elaborate, dynamic and tonal range increased, and a wider range of musical structures were employed than in the Classical era. A growing middle class and increased demand for public concerts led to greater independence of composers from wealthy patrons. Ludwig van Beethoven ushered in the transition from the Classical period to the Romantic with his highly expressive compositions. Other major Romantic composers include Hector Berlioz, Richard Wagner, and Gustav Mahler.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Romantic

TaxonomyNode.Description: Contemporary Classical refers to increasingly divergent developments in art music following the death of serial music composer Anton Webern in 1945, and includes diverse genres such as electroacoustic music, musique concréte, minimalist music, experimental music, post-modern music, spectral music, and sound art.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Contemporary

TaxonomyNode.Description: Western art music composed in the 20th century by composers typically drawing inspiration from modern and postmodern philosophy.
TaxonomyNode.Name: 20th Century

TaxonomyNode.Description: Characterized by the use of guitar and twangy vocals. Instrumentation traditionally includes any of drums, bass, banjo, fiddle, harmonica, electric organ, or steel guitar, though much modern music makes heavier use of pop and rock instrumentation. Originated in the southern United States in the 1920s and influenced by southern folk music tradition, including blues and descendant styles of Scottish, Irish, and English folk traditions.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Country

TaxonomyNode.Description: Strains of country music that developed in the final decades of the 20th century and the early decades of the 21st. Features stronger incorporation of other popular music styles, such as pop, rock, and hip-hop, and often fewer traditional country elements.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Modern Country

TaxonomyNode.Description: Emerged from the folk music of the American South as a phenomenon in the late 1920s. In this decade, Jimmie Rodgers and The Carters were among the first star country music acts. Early country saw folk styles mixed with popular styles such as jazz, pop and rock, with folk sounds fading as the decades went on. Characterized by twang.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Traditional Country

TaxonomyNode.Description: With roots in blues, jazz, and the traditional ballads and dance tunes of the British Isles, by way of Appalachian musical tradition. Pioneered by and named for Bill Monroe and the Blue Grass Boys, who began playing in the style in the mid-1940s. Traditional instrumentation includes the guitar, mandolin, fiddle, banjo and bass, though bluegrass groups may feature other instruments such as the dobro, piano, and accordion. Guitarists typically flatpick, bassists play the root and fifth in a pizzicato style, and fiddlers play in thirds and fifths while vocalists harmonize in two to four parts, often with the highest voice singing dissonant or modal harmony. Bluegrass is often virtuosic and rapidly played. As in jazz, different instruments typically take turns stating and improvising around the melody.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bluegrass

TaxonomyNode.Description: Created primarily by electronic instruments and methods, including manipulation of both digital and circuitry-based forms of audio technology.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Electronic

TaxonomyNode.Description: Emerged among Chicago club DJs in the early 1990s. It is characterized by 4 on the floor kick drums, drum machine rhythms, hi-hat hits on offbeats, and synthesized basslines. It is typically instrumental, though some house music features wordless singing or lyric singing. Prominent early house musicians include Chip E. and Frankie Knuckles.
TaxonomyNode.Name: House

TaxonomyNode.Description: Developed in the late 1980s UK rave scene and in the early 1990s in Germany. It is typically more melodic than contemporary electronic dance music genres, using melody and harmony to build tension and create a sense of progression, and also to build to peaks or drops in the music. It is typically between 110 and 150 BPM, and it prominently features beats as well as more atmospheric, beatless sections, which typically occur after musical climaxes.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Trance

TaxonomyNode.Description: Laid-back, dreamy, and hypnotic electronic music. Usually contains a beat, but is slower and gentler than music intended for dance.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Downtempo

TaxonomyNode.Description: Foregrounds tone and atmosphere over structure and rhythm. Repetitive and slow-paced. It is meant to be able to be listened to both actively and passively. Emerged in the 1960s and 1970s in the United Kingdom, and the style was first described as "ambient" by ambient music pioneer Brian Eno in 1978.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Ambient

TaxonomyNode.Description: Prominently features drum breaks sampled from earlier funk, jazz, and R&B recordings. First emerged as a distinct phenomenon among American hip-hop DJs in the 1970s.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Breakbeat

TaxonomyNode.Description: Inspired by and similar to house music, but is typically faster (120-150 BPM), darker, and more concerned with futuristic themes. Emerged in Detroit in the mid-1980s.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Techno

TaxonomyNode.Description: Characterized by fast tempos (160 BPM and up), intense kicks, synthesized bass, saturation and distortion, similar to industrial music. Prominent in the late 1980s and early 1990s.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Hardcore

TaxonomyNode.Description: Refers both to the traditional folk music of the British Isles and of North America (typically the music of the people, as opposed to classical music - the music of royal courts, aristocracy, and the well-to-do) and to modern genres which primarily take influence from those traditions (particularly during and after the 20th century folk music revival).
TaxonomyNode.Name: Folk

TaxonomyNode.Description: A cappella style usually performed by a close harmony group of four typically male singers taking the roles of bass, baritone, lead, and tenor.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Barbershop Music

TaxonomyNode.Description: Contemporary folk music, which grew out of a 20th century fascination with folk music traditions and which combined those traditions with popular music styles. It includes the music of artists such as Bob Dylan and Joni Mitchell.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Folk Revival

TaxonomyNode.Description: Essentially indie rock with folk (or folk revival) influences. Emerged in the 1990s. The influence of earlier folk is typically strictly musical, as most Indie Folk features only personal lyrics rather than the kinds of political lyrics that are common in folk revival music.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Indie Folk

TaxonomyNode.Description: Sung Christian music with roots in traditional hymns and early African-American spirituals. Often features call and response, and often performed a cappella, with foot stomps and hand claps for rhythmic accompaniment. Gospel can also feature piano, organ, guitar, drums, and other instruments.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Gospel

TaxonomyNode.Description: Sung Christian music with roots in traditional hymns and early African-American spirituals. Often features call and response, and often performed a cappella, with foot stomps and hand claps for rhythmic accompaniment. Gospel can also feature piano, organ, guitar, drums, and other instruments.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Classic Gospel

TaxonomyNode.Description: Typically features rapped vocals (emphasis on rhythm over melody, characteristically verbose compared to other musical styles) over beats. It emerged out of neighborhood block parties as part of a broader hip-hop culture among African-American communities in the Bronx in New York City in the late 1970s.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Hip-Hop

TaxonomyNode.Description: As the term implies, the Golden Age is considered to be the heyday of Hip Hop. During these years, Hip Hop transitioned from regional clusters of musically unique sub-cultures into a global, multi-platinum, mainstream musical force. Despite their success, Hip Hop artists of the Golden Age maintained their sense of roots, innovation, musical diversity, and integrity. Sampling production techniques became an essential ingredient of the genre and lyrical subject principally focused on underlying themes of black identity and socio-political consciousness. Golden Age encompasses the monumental US releases of these years including, Run-DMC's "Rising Against", Public Enemy's "It Takes A Nation Of Millions To Hold Us Back", Beastie Boys' "License To Ill" and KRS-One, Eric B. & Rakim, De La Soul, and A Tribe Call Quest.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Golden Age

TaxonomyNode.Description: Originating on the West Coast through the work of Dr. Dre with Above the Law, G-Funk stood in contrast to many of the dominant Hip Hop sounds of the time. Heavily utilizing P-Funk samples, Dr. Dre and Cold 187um created a form of Rap which sounded much more relaxed and organic than other forms of rap. This was achieved through limiting the amount of samples in a track and dressing them up with live instrumentation. By the mid-1990s, this style proliferated throughout the Midwest and Southern states, becoming, for a period, the dominant form of Hip-Hop. G-Funk was not as common among East Coast rap artists, although artists like Redman would adopt its emphasis on funk samples.
TaxonomyNode.Name: G-Funk

TaxonomyNode.Description: Brazilian rap style that combines musical elements of 1980s Miami bass with the explicit lyrical tropes of gangsta rap. Like Miami bass, beats are typically spare and often feature 80s-style drum machines and synthesizers. Clave rhythms are often prominent in the percussion of more recent recordings. Emerged in the mid-1980s in Rio de Janeiro.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Funk Carioca

TaxonomyNode.Description: Wide-ranging genre characterized by the use of swung rhythms, blue notes, polyrhythms, and particularly, extensive improvisation. It incorporates a wide range of influences, from blues, ragtime, and classical music (particularly that of Impressionist composers such as Debussy), to spirituals and West African cultural and musical traditions. It first emerged as the Dixieland style of music among the African-American communities of New Orleans in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Throughout the 20th century, it developed stylistically across the entire United States, from Kansas City to New York City.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Jazz

TaxonomyNode.Description: Oriented more toward listening than dancing. An intellectual and artistic evolution in jazz. Generally thought to have emerged as a phenomenon in the mid-1940s with bebop and musicians such as Charlie Parker and Dizzy Gillespie.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Modern Jazz

TaxonomyNode.Description: Named for relaxed tempos, gentle tones, and smooth harmonies. Emerged commercially on Miles Davis's Birth of the Cool, and soon became a particularly popular style among white jazz players. Arrangements and compositions were of great importance, occasionally hinting at classical and swing influences.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Cool Jazz

TaxonomyNode.Description: Developed out of earlier forms of jazz such as Dixieland. Swing music incorporated written arrangements to better suit large ensembles (as opposed to Dixieland which relied massively on improvisation). Melodic improvisation only occurs during a solo, and not during the entire duration of the song as in Dixieland. Swing soloists are more inclined to show restraint than soloists in earlier Dixieland music and later styles of jazz such as bebop.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Swing

TaxonomyNode.Description: Jazzy pre-rock pop music. Associated with the repertoire of the "Great American Songbook" and with performers such as Billie Holiday, Frank Sinatra, Rosemary Clooney, and Nat King Cole.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Traditional Pop

TaxonomyNode.Description: With the popularization of Funk music a sub-genre amalgamation of funk and jazz was inevitable. Jazz Funk pulls from funk, soul, R&B and Jazz-- it is a primary form of Fusion. It is one of the first styles of Jazz to incorporate synthesizers.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Jazz Funk

TaxonomyNode.Description: Stemming from the evolution of Fusion in the 1970s, Smooth Jazz highlighted the more polished and gentle side of the then-nascent genre. It subdues improvisation for the sake of groove and rhythm, and is usually characterized by slow tempos and flowing melodies. It utilizes electronic instruments and pulls together strands of Funk, R&B and Jazz.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Smooth Jazz

TaxonomyNode.Description: Umbrella genre that encompasses most music from Spanish or Portuguese speaking areas of the world.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Latin

TaxonomyNode.Description: Reggaeton combines Reggae and Dancehall with Latin American music styles and Hip Hop. The style features rapping or singing, usually in Spanish. Reggaeton originated in Panama and Puerto Rico in the early 1990s.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Reggaeton

TaxonomyNode.Description: Latin Music originating from Mexico.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Regional Mexican

TaxonomyNode.Description: German immigrants living in Texas around the time of the Mexican Revolution combined traditional German music with traditional Mexican music to form Tejano music.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tejano

TaxonomyNode.Description: Popular music, for lack of a better term. Consists almost entirely of short-to-medium length songs, with heavy use of verse-chorus structures and a strong emphasis on melodicism and catchiness. Has no singular sound - often incorporates the popular sounds of the day (thus pop was synonymous with rock through the 60s, picked up elements of EDM in the late 2000s/early 2010s, and often features trap beats in the late 2010s). UMG's bread and butter.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Pop

TaxonomyNode.Description: Sleek, shiny, smooth, and clean, with all its wrinkles smoothed out through extensive production and editing.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Modern Pop

TaxonomyNode.Description: Predominant acoustic timbres and conventional pop song structures.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Acoustic Pop

TaxonomyNode.Description: A wide ranging genre that remains distinctly separate from mainstream pop music.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Alternative Pop

TaxonomyNode.Description: The combination of Pop and Rock music.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Pop Rock

TaxonomyNode.Description: Also known as Música Popular Brasileira, MPB was formed in the late 60s as a modernized form of Bossa Nova and Samba-Cancao. MPB encompasses many non-Brazilian styles of popular music (i.e. American rock/pop/folk/jazz) while retaining its distinct Brazilian identity, partially with use of Portuguese lyrics.
TaxonomyNode.Name: MPB

TaxonomyNode.Description: Cantonese pop music, strongly influenced by Western pop styles.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Cantopop

TaxonomyNode.Description: Mandarin pop music, which followed the rising cultural trend of Cantopop.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Mandopop

TaxonomyNode.Description: Filipino pop music that combines influences from traditional Filipino music, American music, and Spanish/Latin music. Performance is a big component of this music.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Music Of The Philippines (OPM)

TaxonomyNode.Description: Mainly comes out of Indian films. Bollywood and Telugu music are the most popular Indian pop genres.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Indian Pop

TaxonomyNode.Description: Hindi songs featured in Bollywood films. Bollywood songs are India's predominant type of pop music.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bollywood

TaxonomyNode.Description: Indonesian pop music that closely reflects the trends of American, British, Japanese, and Korean pop music cultures.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Indo Pop

TaxonomyNode.Description: Emerged as a distinct genre in the 90s, and is influenced by traditional Japanese music, American Rock and Pop music of the 1960s and 1970s, and earlier popular Japanese music such as the synthpop group Yellow Magic Orchestra.
TaxonomyNode.Name: J-Pop

TaxonomyNode.Description: Korean pop music with strong Western pop music influences and overarching cultural importance in many mediums.
TaxonomyNode.Name: K-Pop

TaxonomyNode.Description: Features an offbeat staccato feel, halftime one drop drum grooves, and socially conscious lyrics. Influenced by mid-century American R&B and jazz, Jamaican ska, and traditional Jamaican music such as mento. Emerged in Jamaica, particularly around Kingston, in the late 1960s. Notable artists include Bob Marley and the Wailers, Toots and the Maytals, and Count Ossie.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Reggae

TaxonomyNode.Description: Features fast tempos, lead horns, and skanking piano and guitar putting emphasis on the backbeat, giving ska a trademark jerky liveliness. Earliest internationally successful style of Jamaican popular music. Incorporates a variety of influences, ranging from New Orleans R&B, jump blues, and jazz to Jamaican mento and Caribbean calypso. Rocksteady and its descendant, reggae, developed as a slower evolution of ska. Ska has spawned international subgenres mingled with punk in the UK and US which maintain the fast tempo and horns of ska, such as 2-Tone and Third Wave.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Ska

TaxonomyNode.Description: Slower descendant of ska. Said to be the result of a hot summer in 1966 and the subsequent need for more relaxed dance music. Like ska, rocksteady features skanking offbeat rhythms and horns, but its perceived tempo is nearly half that of ska, due to a slower harmonic rhythm and lower density of rhythmic events. The slower rhythm creates more space for vocalists and musicians to be melodically expressive. Rocksteady later politicized and spiritualized into reggae.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Rocksteady

TaxonomyNode.Description: Classic reggae - Bob Marley & the Wailers, Burning Spear, Steel Pulse, The Abyssinians, etc. An ideologized descendant of rocksteady, and like that style, sonically typified by skanking guitar, an offbeat emphasis, and low to mid tempos. Lyrics are often political or spiritual, and concern topics from Rastafarianism, poverty, and love to corruption, racial oppression, and liberation. Emerged in the late 1960s and reached its most prominent phase of cultural output in the late 70s.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Roots Reggae

TaxonomyNode.Description: Essentially reggae with vocals removed, heavy emphasis on bass and drums, and extensive use of studio production techniques such as delay, reverb, and dubbing of vocal and instrumental snippets over the beat. The sound is spacious, relaxed, and minimal. Dub was spurred by the popularity of instrumental versions of reggae tracks at sound system parties, and originally began to be commercially released as producer-led instrumental B-sides of 45 rpm reggae singles in the late 1960s. The style gained popularity and developed its own following, creating its own star artists, such as the melodicist Augustus Pablo and the producer King Tubby. Often cited as a major precursor to and forefather of contemporary electronic dance music - the concept of remixing is believed to have originated with dub.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Dub

TaxonomyNode.Description: Originally a marketing term for popular African-American music with a strong beat, R&B has since come to define a few specific styles that are perhaps as much sonic as racial categories. The term has several distinct associated sounds, depending on the era. In the early 50s, R&B described popular blues records, and in the mid-50s, the term came to denote gospel and soul music, as well as popular styles with elements of electric blues, acoustically similar to contemporary rock and roll (which itself grew out of early R&B). In the 70s, it largely referred to soul and funk, and in the 80s, the term began to refer to a sonic hybrid of earlier R&B, pop, soul, funk, rap, and electronic music. It has morphed and evolved while maintaining this hybrid identity to the present day, taking on newer production and performance styles as time passes.
TaxonomyNode.Name: R&B

TaxonomyNode.Description: Smooth-sounding, with many electronic elements - drum machines, synthesizers and generally electronic timbres predominate, along with lush vocal arrangements, creative production, and extensive use of pitch corrected vocals.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Contemporary R&B

TaxonomyNode.Description: R&B (modern) describes the modern fusion of soul gospel and funk with modern production techniques and technologies including sampling and synthesis.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Modern R&B

TaxonomyNode.Description: A catch-all term referring to the first several decades of R&B's existence -- during which the genre emphasized blues- like rhythms, tight and spare instrumentation, and vocal groups.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Traditional R&B

TaxonomyNode.Description: Developed in the African American community combining influences from traditional Gospel Music, Rhythm & Blues, and Rock n' Roll. Some notable artists are Ray Charles, James Brown, and Sam Cooke.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Soul

TaxonomyNode.Description: Retro Soul is the carbon copy re-creation of the musically-defining ingredients of the classic era of soul typically including the replication of vintage production aesthetics instrumentation arrangements and songwriting style.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Retro Soul

TaxonomyNode.Description: Named after the legendary Detroit record label founded by Berry Gordy, Motown was the first African-American owned label featuring African-American artists to achieve American mainstream popular success. The "Motown Sound" characterized by soft, smooth, soulful vocals over simple, straight-forward arrangements with highly memorable melodic hooks echoing throughout the instrumentation. Motown's success and distinctive sound can be attributed to the use of the same songwriters, producers, musicians and studio for every recording. Notably, the Funk Brothers, a group of highly-talented session musicians who helped defined the sound and craft of Motown's music.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Motown Sound

TaxonomyNode.Description: Created in the 1960s in the African American community as a blending of Soul, Jazz, and R&B. The genre deemphasizes melody and focuses on groove and bassline.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Funk

TaxonomyNode.Description: Dance music style that originated in the United States in the early to late 1970s that fuses R&B, Funk & Soul music. Unlike the simpler four-piece band sound of the funk & soul of the late 1960s, disco music often included vocalists, with several chordal instruments (guitar, keyboards, synthesizer), several drum or percussion instruments (drumkit, Latin percussion, electronic drums), a horn section, a string orchestra, and a variety of "classical" solo instruments. Not coincidentally Disco was generally a producer led genre rather than as centered as much around the artists as other genres.
