As a genre that introduced dj's, dance clubs, extended mixes and remixes, Disco is the true beginning and basis for all dance music
TaxonomyNode.Name: Disco

TaxonomyNode.Description: Song-focused, typically electric guitar-centric and beat-driven genre that emerged in the 1940s and 50s from blues, R&B and country music. Many variants and styles exist, though most feature at least electric guitar, bass, drums, and a lead singer.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Rock

TaxonomyNode.Description: Wide-ranging subgenre of rock music, originally underground, or (since the 90s, especially) mainstream but with roots in and major influence from prior underground music, such as punk.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Alternative Rock

TaxonomyNode.Description: Characterized by a thick, massive sound with highly amplified distortion, extended guitar solos, and emphatic beats. The genre was pioneered by the bands Led Zeppelin, Black Sabbath, and Deep Purple. Metal music has since split into many sub genres.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Metal

TaxonomyNode.Description: Born in the 1970s out of 1960s garage music. Focused on the rejection of mainstream music and culture. Punk rock featured short fast-paced songs with simple instrumentation and harsh guitar and vocal tone. Some notable artists include Ramones, The Clash, and Sex Pistols.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Punk

TaxonomyNode.Description: Mainstream rock styles prevalent before the 90s.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Early Rock

TaxonomyNode.Description: The timeless rock format of the 1960s and 1970s. Hints of glam and psychedelia with the raw energy and palatability of 1960s Pop Rock.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Classic Rock

TaxonomyNode.Description: Smoother sounding than hard rock, with melodic songs and lush production.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Soft Rock

TaxonomyNode.Description: Rock that does not use electric instruments.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Acoustic Rock

TaxonomyNode.Description: Characterized by atypical sounds, arrangements, performance techniques, or production techniques.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Experimental Rock

TaxonomyNode.Description: Primarily non-musical and focused on the spoken word.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Spoken

TaxonomyNode.Description: Theatrical recording, often humorous. Common on rap albums.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Skit

TaxonomyNode.Description: A comic style in which a comedian performs in front of a live audience.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Stand-Up Comedy

TaxonomyNode.Description: A descriptive spoken account of events, usually as they occur.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Commentary

TaxonomyNode.Description: Reciting of a poem. Evokes vivid emotions, while having some form of style or rhythm.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Poetry

TaxonomyNode.Description: Folk and court music traditions outside of North America and the British Isles.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Traditional

TaxonomyNode.Description: Influenced mostly by West African Music and Spanish Music. Traditional forms include Changüí, Coros de clave, Kiribá, Nengón, and Tumba francesa
TaxonomyNode.Name: Cuban

TaxonomyNode.Description: Traditional Irish music was usually either for singing or dancing. Folk music in Ireland used instruments such as harps, woodwinds, hornpipes, trumpets and bones.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Irish

TaxonomyNode.Description: Traditional North American Music can range from the music of indigenous North American People to Early American Folk songs.
TaxonomyNode.Name: North American

TaxonomyNode.Description: Traditional music of Andalusian Romani. Flamenco was thought to have started with the migration of Indian gypsies traveling through the middle east and eventually settling in Spain and therefore has many middle eastern and Spanish influences. The music has endured much political backlash throughout its history. Flamenco is characterized by its unique virtuosic singing and guitar playing. The instruments used are the voice, guitar and palmas (hand clapping), as those were the instruments that the Romani gypsies could bring on their travels. Flamenco dancing is a fundamental Flamenco genre and culture, and Flamenco music often accompanies dancing.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Flamenco

TaxonomyNode.Description: Fusion of various Western popular music genres with different global folk music styles.
TaxonomyNode.Name: World

TaxonomyNode.Description: Quality of energy.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Emotion

TaxonomyNode.Description: Strong, uncomfortable and hostile response to a perceived provocation, hurt or threat.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Angry

TaxonomyNode.Description: Tension, uneasiness and worry in reaction to thoughts of a potential future threat.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Anxious

TaxonomyNode.Description: General emotional suffering.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Pained

TaxonomyNode.Description: Distressing emotion aroused by the perception of impending danger.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Fearful

TaxonomyNode.Description: Pensive sadness with no necessary or obvious cause.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Melancholic

TaxonomyNode.Description: Emotional pain associated with, or characterized by feelings of disadvantage, loss, despair, grief, helplessness, disappointment and sorrow.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Sad

TaxonomyNode.Description: Enthusiastic, high-energy state.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Exciting

TaxonomyNode.Description: Light, pleasurable, and joyful.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Happy

TaxonomyNode.Description: Positive and cheerful.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Uplifting

TaxonomyNode.Description: Fanciful and powerfully sentimental.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Romantic

TaxonomyNode.Description: Silky smooth and seductive.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Sensual

TaxonomyNode.Description: Pleasant and cute.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Sweet

TaxonomyNode.Description: Mild happiness and satisfaction; at ease.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Contented

TaxonomyNode.Description: A euphoric positive state of consciousness.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Blissful

TaxonomyNode.Description: Uplifting in a way that encourages progress.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Inspiring

TaxonomyNode.Description: Big, inspiring, and melodic. Think "We Will Rock You".
TaxonomyNode.Name: Anthemic

TaxonomyNode.Description: Warm and cozy.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Intimate

TaxonomyNode.Description: Expressive and dynamic, with sweeping emotions, affecting and theatrical.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Dramatic

TaxonomyNode.Description: Intense, focused, sober, humorless and stern.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Serious

TaxonomyNode.Description: Tension, unease, and a sense of anticipation.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Suspenseful

TaxonomyNode.Description: Self-assured and bold.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Confident

TaxonomyNode.Description: Hot, lustful and erotic.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Sexual

TaxonomyNode.Description: Tender, nostalgic, poignant and sensitive.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Sentimental

TaxonomyNode.Description: Stately and splendorous.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Majestic

TaxonomyNode.Description: Strange in a silly and awkward way.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Quirky

TaxonomyNode.Description: Enigmatic, secretive, and cryptic.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Mysterious

TaxonomyNode.Description: Ethereal, cloud-like, and floating.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Dreamy

TaxonomyNode.Description: Joyful and lacking in seriousness.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Lighthearted

TaxonomyNode.Description: Obscure, unpredictable, and unusual.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Abstract

TaxonomyNode.Description: Passionless and indifferent.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Apathetic

TaxonomyNode.Description: Innocent, fun, and light.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Playful

TaxonomyNode.Description: Funny and whimsically amusing.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Comical

TaxonomyNode.Description: Vast and extremely serious.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Epic

TaxonomyNode.Description: Film-like - with gravitas, seems to carry weight.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Cinematic

TaxonomyNode.Description: Quantity of energy.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Intensity

TaxonomyNode.Description: Extremely high dynamic level, likely high rhythmic density and likely with a strong sense of rapid movement, though seemingly motionless but extremely tense and loud walls of sound can also meet the definition.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Highest Intensity

TaxonomyNode.Description: Strong sense of movement with a medium to high dynamic level and likely high rhythmic density.
TaxonomyNode.Name: High Intensity

TaxonomyNode.Description: Bubbling just under the surface of High Intensity, with medium to high rhythmic density and dynamic level, a strong sense of movement, and likely a significant beat or percussive element.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Medium-High Intensity

TaxonomyNode.Description: Not very mellow, but not particularly driving or intense either.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Medium Intensity

TaxonomyNode.Description: Low to medium dynamic level, with more of a pronounced sense of movement and possibly more of a beat or percussive presence than Low Intensity, though still relatively mellow.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Medium-Low Intensity

TaxonomyNode.Description: Regular but relaxed movement, subtle or no percussive elements, low to mid rhythmic density, and a generally low dynamic level.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Low Intensity

TaxonomyNode.Description: Movement that is infrequent or so plain and regular as to be hypnotic, low rhythmic density, low dynamic level, and likely no percussive elements.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Lowest Intensity

TaxonomyNode.Description: Varying intensity throughout.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Dynamic

TaxonomyNode.Description: Tempo is the Pulse Over Time measured in Beats Per Minute (i.e. BPM)
TaxonomyNode.Name: Tempo

TaxonomyNode.Description: Instrumental, a cappella or in between? What identifiable compositional techniques are employed?
TaxonomyNode.Name: Arrangement

TaxonomyNode.Description: Instrumental Ensemble Only
TaxonomyNode.Name: Instrumental

TaxonomyNode.Description: Contains Instruments and Vocals.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Voice & Music

TaxonomyNode.Description: Solo or Group Voices without instrumental accompaniment.
TaxonomyNode.Name: A Cappella

TaxonomyNode.Description: A collection of songs often sharing a common theme.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Playlist

TaxonomyNode.Description: Music intended for performance at wedding ceremonies
TaxonomyNode.Name: Wedding

TaxonomyNode.Description: A popular song by an artist that is generally their only hit.
TaxonomyNode.Name: One Hit Wonder

TaxonomyNode.Description: ...is coming.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Winter

TaxonomyNode.Description: The organization of instruments.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Ensemble

TaxonomyNode.Description: What kind of musical ensemble?
TaxonomyNode.Name: Ensemble Configuration

TaxonomyNode.Description: Large jazz ensemble, typically comprised of saxophones, trombones, trumpets, and a rhythm section of piano, electric guitar, upright bass and drums.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Big Band

TaxonomyNode.Description: Traditional marching band with bagpipes and drums.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Pipe Band

TaxonomyNode.Description: Mexican band made up of guitarrón mexicano, guitarra de golpe, vihuela, guitar, and sometimes trumpet, flute, accordion, and violin. Mariachi bands play in the Son Style with great influence from the Polka and Waltz genres.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Mariachi Band

TaxonomyNode.Description: A concert style band featuring brass, woodwind, and percussion instruments.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Wind Ensemble

TaxonomyNode.Description: Consists of a dominant electric bass, along with electric guitar, drum set, a singer, and often a horn section or synthesizer.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Reggae Band

TaxonomyNode.Description: Predominant voice accompanied by a single instrument, typically guitar, piano, or another typical accompaniment instrument.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Voice & Accompaniment

TaxonomyNode.Description: Rock Ensemble, typically a Quartet, defined by Distorted Electric Guitar, Electric Bass and Drums
TaxonomyNode.Name: Rock Band

TaxonomyNode.Description: Pop Ensemble, typically a Quintet, defined by Acoustic and Electric Guitar, Electric Bass, Piano, Keyboards, Synthesizers, Percussion and Drums
TaxonomyNode.Name: Pop Band

TaxonomyNode.Description: A large group of instrumentalists consisting of sections of strings, brass, woodwinds, and percussion
TaxonomyNode.Name: Orchestra

TaxonomyNode.Description: A band made up of brass instruments and commonly a percussion section.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Brass Band

TaxonomyNode.Description: A band with brass, woodwind, and percussion instruments, which marches around while playing.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Marching Band

TaxonomyNode.Description: Latin Ensemble, typically a minimum of a trio, defined by Winds, Brass, Upright or Electric Bass, Piano and Latin Percussion
TaxonomyNode.Name: Latin Band

TaxonomyNode.Description: Small jazz ensemble which features at least three players, often comprised of piano, upright bass and drums, often in addition to one or more melodic instruments (i.e. brass, winds, guitars).
TaxonomyNode.Name: Jazz Combo

TaxonomyNode.Description: Folk Ensemble, large or small, typically defined by a combined selection of Acoustic Instruments of the World
TaxonomyNode.Name: Folk Band

TaxonomyNode.Description: Country Ensemble, typically a Quintet, defined by Acoustic and Electric Guitar, Lap Steel, Pedal Steel, Dobro, Banjo, Upright or Electric Bass, Piano, Fiddle, Percussion and Drums
TaxonomyNode.Name: Country Band

TaxonomyNode.Description: A small to medium sized Ensemble comprised of 'non-traditional' instrument configurations
TaxonomyNode.Name: Chamber Ensemble

TaxonomyNode.Description: A marching band consisting of fifes and drums.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Fife & Drum Corps

TaxonomyNode.Description: Predominant single instrument accompanied by a single instrument, typically guitar, piano, or another typical accompaniment instrument.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Instrument & Accompaniment

TaxonomyNode.Description: Means of sound production.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Ensemble Timbre

TaxonomyNode.Description: An object or device for producing musical sounds.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Instrument

TaxonomyNode.Description: Six-stringed, fretted instrument. It is typically played with both hands by strumming or plucking the strings with either a guitar pick or the finger/fingernails of one hand, while simultaneously fretting with the fingers of the other hand.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Guitar

TaxonomyNode.Description: A guitar that produces sound acoustically by transmitting the vibration of the strings to the air—as opposed to relying on electronic amplification.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Acoustic Guitar

TaxonomyNode.Description: A guitar that uses one or more pickups to convert the vibration of its strings into electrical signals, which are then sent through an amplifier.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Electric Guitar

TaxonomyNode.Description: The largest and lowest member of either the guitar or viol family that typically has 4-6 strings.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Bass

TaxonomyNode.Description: Various drums set up together and played by a single performer. Typical instruments included are the kick drum, snare drum, toms, hi-hat, and cymbals.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Drum Set

TaxonomyNode.Description: Electronic instrument which sequences patterns for synthesized or sampled drum sounds.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Drum Machine

TaxonomyNode.Description: An electronic musical instrument that generates audio signals via oscillators.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Synthesizer

TaxonomyNode.Description: Any instrument primarily distinguished by its use of the Western musical keyboard.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Keyboard

TaxonomyNode.Description: Keyboard instrument with chromatic keys which, when pressed, move hammers to hit strings in the body of the instrument. There are also foot pedals for dampening and sustaining the sound.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Piano

TaxonomyNode.Description: Instruments that are struck either with sticks, mallets, or hands to produce sound.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Percussion

TaxonomyNode.Description: Instruments that produce sound from vibrating strings when the performer plays the strings in some manner, usually by bowing, plucking, or striking.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Strings

TaxonomyNode.Description: An instrument that contains some type of resonator (usually a tube), in which a column of air is set into vibration by the player blowing into (or over) a mouthpiece set at or near the end of the resonator.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Wind

TaxonomyNode.Description: Keyboard instrument which produces sound by blowing air through pipes or across reeds.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Organ

TaxonomyNode.Description: Family of box-shaped bellows-driven free-reed aerophones. Played by compressing or expanding the bellows while pressing buttons or keys, causing pallets to open, which allow air to flow across strips of brass or steel called reeds. These vibrate to produce sound inside the body. Valves on opposing reeds of each note are used to make the instrument's reeds sound louder without air leaking from each reed block. The performer normally plays the melody on buttons or keys on the right-hand manual, and the accompaniment, consisting of bass and pre-set chord buttons, on the left-hand manual.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Accordion

TaxonomyNode.Description: Voice describes Vocal qualities including Arrangement, Gender, Technique, Accompaniment, Delivery and Effects.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Voice

TaxonomyNode.Description: The main vocal performer on a song recording.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Lead Vocals

TaxonomyNode.Description: Boy Voice.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Boy

TaxonomyNode.Description: Child's Voice, male or female.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Child

TaxonomyNode.Description: Female Voice.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Female

TaxonomyNode.Description: Girl Voice.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Girl

TaxonomyNode.Description: Male Voice.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Male

TaxonomyNode.Description: Various kinds of choir and vocal group.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Vocal Ensemble

TaxonomyNode.Description: >11 vocal performers
TaxonomyNode.Name: Choir

TaxonomyNode.Description: Two featured Solo Voices in featured conversation.
TaxonomyNode.Name: Vocal Duet
